Hi Grace,
This is Jeff from 
Calendly
 with some tips and product updates to make meetings easier and more productive.
Tip of the Day: You Deserve to 
Get Paid
You should be 
charging people money to “pick your brain” in a video call
. To give them feedback on their startup. To teach them about your profession. To consult at night after your long workday. To demo their product. To coach them each week. To teach them yoga or exercise or art or music.
Yes, we should all volunteer to help people who don’t have the means to pay us. However, many of the people who reach out to you on LinkedIn do.
The “side hustles” to create another revenue stream in 2022 are now the necessary protection you need in an uncertain economy in 2024.
Join me and thousands of others, and 
connect your Calendly to PayPal or Stripe and start charging for meetings
 (available on the 
Standard subscription plan
 and higher).
You don’t need to request people pay for every meeting if you have 
multiple event types
 that you offer, but reserve one event type with 
PayPal
 or 
Stripe
 integrated – just in case. 
Charge for Meetings
Back That Event Type Up
As you know, Calendly Event Types are how you offer your attendees blocks of time to meet with you (e.g., 30-minute video call, 15-minute in-person visit, 45-minute paid consultation).
Sometimes you need a little backup when coordinating meetings. That’s why we recently expanded 
event type permissions
, allowing you to add editors and viewers to your own events 
and
 admin-managed events!
Collaborators can make event updates that help you deliver the best customer and candidate experience, prepare event types for you to speed up scheduling, and share event links on your behalf for a seamless handoff.
Try Permissions
Improved Collective and Round Robin Event Types
When I ask people in companies what their favorite Calendly feature is, they generally say our 
collaborative scheduling features
 to schedule better together as a team.
These team-scheduling pros wanted more, though. Dozens of them emailed asking for the ability to share meetings among groups of coworkers, or what we call 
Collective 
plus
 Round Robin
.
Available on the 
Teams and Enterprise subscription plans
, you can now mix and match Collective and Round Robin capabilities to easily get a combination of teammates scheduled. For example, you can improve: 
Product demos to prospects:
 Set up an event type with an account executive plus one of five rotating sales engineers
Panel interviews:
 Pair a hiring manager with one of three rotating team leaders plus one of four rotating peers interviewers
New customer onboarding calls:
 Include a sales manager who closed the deal plus their assigned customer success manager and one of four rotating technical implementation specialists
Try Collective and Round Robin
Join Your Calendly Community
Have you ever wanted to 
meet other Calendly users
? What about ask them questions? Or answer theirs? We’ve got you covered with the new

Whether you’re just getting started making your scheduling more efficient or a seasoned pro, this community has something for you.

subject: Webinar: Finding and Securing the Future of the Credit Union Movement in the Age of Digital Transformation
body:
You don't often get email from events@woccu.org.

Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
Webinar: 
Finding and Securing the Future of the Credit Union Movement in the Age of Digital Transformation
Time: Wednesday, January 31st at 10:00 am CT
A transformation is underway in the global financial services industry that will have a profound impact on how participants do business, how they strategize about their futures and how they collaborate around products, service and information. During this session, Mark will highlight four Mega-Trends: how the financial services business model is changing; how new entrants are disrupting the industry though innovation; how technology is changing the nature of financial services delivery and distribution; and, how demographic shifts require financial firms to adapt their cultures and value propositions to gain market share especially among younger consumers.
In this webinar, participants will learn:
Understand the primary drivers and impacts of Digital Transformation on the global financial services industry.
Gain a deeper understanding of the changing behaviors and preferences of different consumer demographics.
Review the strategic imperatives necessary to build the Credit Union of tomorrow.
This webinar is presented by:
Mark Sievewright, Chief Credit Union Strategist & Founder, Sievewright & Associates, a Strategic Resource Management Company, USA
This webinar is sponsored by:

subject: Doubling down on impact: A message from Mike Reuter
body:
You don't often get email from foundation@woccu.org. 
Learn why this is important
Read this in your browser.
Doubling down on impact: Our vision for 2024 and beyond
 
As the new year gets well underway, I want to give a heartfelt thanks for your support in 2023 and bring you in on our vision for 2024 and beyond. 
 
At a time when the wealth gap has never been greater and financial wellness remains out of reach for so many, our work to strengthen the global credit union system and bridge the gap to financial services is vital.
 
Our 
2023 Impact Report
 shows how your support enabled us to carry out this critical work, furthering economic inclusion and prosperity around the world. 
 
In 2024, we’re doubling down on impact. Our commitment to bridging gaps remains paramount, but we’ll deliver our work through a refined strategy that emphasizes and encourages collaboration on a global scale. Only by living the cooperative principles can we bring financial services to the 1.4 billion people who woke up without them today.
 
For many of them, digitized services are an unimaginable luxury—one that would make a profound difference in the economic security and prosperity of their families, businesses, and communities. With your support, we are capitalizing programs focused on digitalization, bringing scale to credit unions serving some of the most remote communities.
 
For others, gender is a barrier to financial wellness. Addressing that is a core concern of our Global Women’s Leadership Network (GWLN). This worldwide sisterhood is informing, educating and inspiring change to create greater financial opportunities for women.
 
Elsewhere, daily circumstances can be so perilous that access to financial services is simply untenable. But because of donors like you supporting our Project Storm Break initiative, we’re providing on-the-ground support—in war-torn nations and in communities recovering from devastating natural disasters—helping credit union employees and members recover and rebuild.
 
To ensure the long-term impact of and scale of this work, we’re also committed to supporting and nurturing the next generation of credit union leaders through the World Young Credit Union Professionals (WYCUP) network. 
 
Throughout 2024, I intend to engage you—as Worldwide Foundation champions and credit union leaders—more frequently and more openly. I want to source and solicit your feedback and input as valued partners, maximizing our progress, process and impact.
 
Thank you all for your continued support. I look forward to taking on this next challenge with all of you. 
 
 
Sincerely,
Michael Reuter
Worldwide Foundation Executive Director
World Council of Credit Unions (WOCCU)
 
 
A registered charity organization with
P.O. Box 2982 • Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA • 
Foundation@woccu.org
 • DoGlobalGood.org

subject: Global Women’s Leadership Network Awards Four Scholarships
body:
Read this in your browser.
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
2024-01-22
Global Women’s Leadership Network Awards Four Scholarships
Scholars to attend WCUC for learning opportunities in 2024
 
2023 Scholars attending WCUC 2023 in Vancouver, CA
 
2023 Virtual Scholars
MADISON, Wis.—
Global Women’s Leadership Network
 (GWLN) awarded four scholarships to credit union industry women, providing them with opportunities for professional development and skill diversification at the largest gathering of credit union professionals at the World Credit Union Conference (WCUC), along with several virtual events throughout the year. 
The 2024 GWLN Scholarship recipients are: 
Gugu Vilakati (Eswatini) 
Grace Akinyi Ogolla Watsiera (Kenya) 
Raquel Mascariña (Philippines)  
Michelle Carrera (USA) 
Scholars will receive the complimentary registration to the 
World Credit Union Conference
 (WCUC) in Boston, USA from July 21-24, co-hosted by 
World Council of Credit Unions
 (WOCCU) and 
America’s Credit Unions
, 
as well as travel, hotel accommodation and a stipend. 
“We’re very excited to be able to continue our tradition of annual scholarships this year with the support of our industry partners and membership base. These four scholars were selected from a record number of 86 applicants from 23 countries on six continents where GWLN is present,” said Lena Giakoumopoulos, GWLN Director. “There were a large number of well qualified individuals, and it was a challenge to select these four women who will build their skillsets, help grow our program and engage with more women for a greater impact throughout the global credit union system.” 
Since 2009, GWLN has awarded more than 100 scholarships to women from over 30 countries. 
Scholarships are made possible through funding from GWLN memberships and industry champion sponsorships. In 2023, sponsors included 
PSCU
/
Co-op Solutions
, 
TruStage
, 
Origence
 and the Susan Adams Scholarship Fund which was established in honor of former Entrust Financial Credit Union CEO Susan Adams supported by 
One AZ Credit Union
. 
Global Women’s Leadership Network connects, inspires, and empowers women with the opportunities and resources to make a measurable difference …  in the lives of each other, in the lives of credit union members and in their communities. To learn more about GWLN, visit 
CUWomen.org
.
 
The Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions, as a strategic partner of the World Council, bridges gaps impacting credit unions' ability to grow and advance financial inclusion worldwide. Our commitment to provide global credit union journeys augments our shared vision with World Council's of realizing a vibrant and growing global credit union movement. Worldwide Foundation's philanthropy advances World Council's technical capacity to strengthen credit union systems that advance financial inclusion to underserved communities.
 
Contact: 
Rachel Miller
E-mail: 
rmiller@woccu.org
Phone: 
608-395-2036
 
 
A registered charity organization with
P.O. Box 2982 • Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA • 
Foundation@woccu.org
 • DoGlobalGood.org

unsubscribe from this list

subject: Author of “The Bold Ones” to speak at WCUC
body:
You don't often get email from events@woccu.org. 
Learn why this is important
Innovation strategist and bestselling author Shawn Kanungo joins World Credit Union Conference lineup
The business world has fundamentally changed forever. The growth and adoption of new technologies is at a dizzying pace. Customer and employee expectations have been pushed forward 10 years due to the pandemic. We are now looking for organizations to be fearless in a changing world.
These drivers are forcing everyone to reimagine their entire organizations. How do we survive? How do we disrupt ourselves before someone else does? How do we deliver better experiences to our clients, customers, and teams? Today, we need to be bold, brave, and experimental.
In this awe-inspiring talk, 
Shawn Kanungo
 provides an optimistic roadmap for the future. He explores how we can take unexpected approaches to innovation to remain competitive and relevant.
Want a sneak peek? You can stream his special “Shawn Kanungo: The Bold Ones” on Apple TV and Amazon Prime today.
Don’t miss this inspiring talk at the largest global credit union conference of the year! Early-bird pricing is still in effect. Grab your spot now.

subject: Webinar: Finding and Securing the Future of the Credit Union Movement in the Age of Digital Transformation
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
Webinar: 
Finding and Securing the Future of the Credit Union Movement in the Age of Digital Transformation
Time: Wednesday, January 31st at 10:00 am CT
A transformation is underway in the global financial services industry that will have a profound impact on how participants do business, how they strategize about their futures and how they collaborate around products, service and information. During this session, Mark will highlight four Mega-Trends: how the financial services business model is changing; how new entrants are disrupting the industry though innovation; how technology is changing the nature of financial services delivery and distribution; and, how demographic shifts require financial firms to adapt their cultures and value propositions to gain market share especially among younger consumers.
In this webinar, participants will learn:
Understand the primary drivers and impacts of Digital Transformation on the global financial services industry.
Gain a deeper understanding of the changing behaviors and preferences of different consumer demographics.
Review the strategic imperatives necessary to build the Credit Union of tomorrow.
This webinar is presented by:
Mark Sievewright, Chief Credit Union Strategist & Founder, Sievewright & Associates, a Strategic Resource Management Company, USA
This webinar is sponsored by:

subject: GlobalWA Year in Review
body:
You don't often get email from comms@globalwa.org. 
Learn why this is important
 
2023 Issue Campaigns - Year in Review
 
In 2023 we saw many of our members travelling again, reinvigorated by the chance to visit their in-country programs. The energy was high, and though there were still disasters, conflicts, and climate change affecting the globe, our members and their constituents showed enduring signs of hope and resilience. 
 
You can read about our members’ accomplishments, strategies, and future-thinking in the articles referenced below. We also encourage you to explore our very active 
Blog
 
section with more than 30 member Guest Blogs published. Season 1 of our 
Goalmakers Podcast
 culminated with a total of 12 episodes! Along with several event-based episodes we had insightful and inspiring conversations with our members' leaders and experts.
 
 
The year culminated in the publication of our new 
2024 Global Philanthropy Guide
, and a very highly praised 
Goalmakers 2023 Annual Conference
.
 
We also encourage you to take a look at our 
2024 Editorial Calendar
 to see what is coming up in 2024! If you are a GlobalWA member, please 
let us know
 if you are interested in being featured in any of the upcoming issues.
 
 
 
Visit our 
2023 Year in Review: Re-cap of GlobalWA Issue Campaigns post
 to read more about this past year's issues, or link through to a specific Issue Campaign below:
 
MARCH – Disabilities and Inclusive Development:
 The words “inclusive development” can spark many concepts within the global development community. The concept of inclusivity as it applies to people with physical or mental disabilities is often overlooked. We discuss in this month’s Issue Campaign how several Global Washington members are providing services, advocating, and changing health systems to improve the lives of people with disabilities. 
Read more »
 
 
Athletics competition at the Special Olympics Malta Invitational Games 2022. Photo: Special Olympics
 
APRIL – Education and Gender Equality:
 This issue campaign on gender equality and education highlights Global Washington members working on gender equity to advance girls’ education. Increases in gender equality in low- and middle-income countries can improve the pathways and support for quality education for girls. An increase in women in the workforce and leadership position provides powerful examples for the next generation and can spark a cultural shift to increase the value of girls’ education. It also provides the progression from education to jobs that is need for girls to stay within their communities and creates stronger societal cohesion. 
Read more »
 
  
Young Indian schoolgirl. Photo: Pixabay
 
MAY/JUNE – Climate Change and No Hunger:
 The Pacific Northwest is known for innovation, technology, engineering, and an awareness to mitigate the damaging effects of climate change. That ethos is evident in our Global Washington members who are creating climate solutions that increase food security and reach the Sustainable Development Goal 2 of Zero Hunger. This includes sustainable and resilient agriculture that are both high-tech and low-tech informed by proven indigenous knowledge. This Issue Brief talks about challenges and innovations from our members. 
Read more »
 
  
Water irrigation valves on an African farm. Photo: Toodlingstudio/Pixabay
 
 
JULY – Supporting Refugees:
 Over the past two years, there has been a dramatic increase in the number of people forcibly displaced around the world. 19 million people left their homes in 2022 due to conflict, violence, climate change, and other factors making their living situation unbearable. This brought the total number of refugees and displaced people to 108.4 million – a staggering number of people – and solutions for support and resettlement are becoming increasingly challenging. Our Issue Campaign describes the programs that are helping refugees to find safe places and services due to the efforts of Global Washington members. 
Read more »
 
 
Afghan children. Photo: Pixabay
 
AUGUST – Our New Pangea Giving Program:
 Our Issue Campaign this month introduced Pangea Giving, now a GlobalWA program, to the broader GlobalWA community. This included an interview with a Pangea Giving grantee, Executive Director Robert Kalulu of Child Empowerment Programme in Uganda; an interview with Pangea board members about the power and importance of site visits; and an article by one of the Pangea founders, Allan Paulson, about the founding and core principles that have guided Pangea since their formation in 2003. 
Read more »
 
  
The Pangea team with four mothers with children in Dandelion’s programs. Photo: Pangea
 
SEPTEMBER – Economic Empowerment:
 Building a system of sustainable economic prosperity and employment opportunities afforded to all, the core of Sustainable Development Goal 8, is a process designed to impact other sectors of development in tandem – such as the alleviation of poverty, the promise of Goal 1. With global unemployment projected to reach 208 million in 2023, alongside accelerating costs of living, solutions that empower workers with skills and opportunities can not only address the goal of sustainable economic growth, but actively raise underprivileged groups out of poverty. Our Issue Campaign for September spoke to how several of our members are approaching these challenges and the solutions they have implemented. 
Read more »
  
Ethiopian farmers at market. Photo: Erik Hathaway/Unsplash
 
OCTOBER – Food Security:
 The World Food Programme estimates that 345 million people are facing acute food insecurity in 2023, and that the proliferation of armed conflict and civil unrest are the main drivers. Tragically, this will only increase in the coming months with recent wars and long-standing political instability in countries around the world. Critical emergency food relief will be needed as the first step to get communities on a path to food security defined in Sustainable Development Goal 2 of Zero Hunger. We explored these issues in this month's Issue Campaign and exemplified our members’ programs addressing hunger in the communities where they work. 
Read more »
 
  
Children eating a meal at their school; Ghana. Photo: Bill Wegener/Unsplash
 
NOVEMBER – Conference planning and Goalmaker Podcasts:
 Throughout November, in lieu of an Issue Campaign, we put concerted energy into fine-tuning our Goalmakers 2023 Conference. Additionally, we were able to publish a small backlog of 
Goalmaker Podcasts
, including Jennifer Jones, President of Rotary International; Tim Prewitt, President and CEO of The Hunger Project; Surita Sandosham, President and CEO of Heifer International with Randi Hedin, Board Chair for Heifer International; and Anjali Makhija, Trustee and CEO, S.M. Sehgal Foundation.
 
 
DECEMBER – 2024 GLOBAL PHILANTHROPY GUIDE:
 In this year’s edition of the Philanthropy Guide, you’ll read stories of non-profit organizations working to educate youth in low- and middle-income countries. However, the value of these programs goes far beyond an academic education for individual students. These organizations provide essential social-emotional learning, health and hygiene, and a safe space that can be a lifeline for youth. In fact, studies show that communities without access to education have an increase in early marriage, forced labor, and child trafficking. 
 
The organizations listed in this Philanthropy Guide are providing that hope for children in Afghanistan, Laos, Bangladesh, Uganda, Brazil, India, Peru, and other regions throughout the world. In addition, at the back of this guide you will find a full directory of Global Washington’s more than 100 members, including descriptions of their work. 
Download the 2024 Global Philanthropy Guide »
 
 
NOVEMBER 30 + DECEMBER 7 – 2023 GOALMAKERS ANNUAL CONFERENCE:
 Our 2023 Goalmakers Conference was a huge success! The theme resonated with everyone in our GlobalWA community, and the breakout sessions were timely and relevant. Our 29 sessions featured 68 speakers from across the globe. The 300 attendees were engaged throughout the days, both in-person and using our conference app called Whova. The interactions on Whova reflect the community-building and connections that we want to continue throughout the year. The quality of experience for attendees exceeded pre-pandemic levels with the inclusion of a virtual day, an increase in participation from those outside the U.S., and more interactive sessions. You can view the conference sessions, speaker bios, sponsors and more 
here »
 
Plenary panel at our 2023 Goalmakers Annual Conference. Photo: Joel Meyers

subject: Just announced: World Credit Union Conference keynote speaker
body:
The “Oprah of Management Thinkers” joins the agenda
As a credit union leader, you understand the vital role strong teams play in serving your members. That's why we're excited to announce 
Erica Dhawan's
 keynote session on Concrete Empathy at the World Credit Union Conference.
In this transformative session, discover Erica’s playbook for modern team leadership with learnings that go beyond conventional approaches. The “Oprah of Management Thinkers” and a leading authority on teamwork and innovative leadership, Erica will offer practical ways to activate Concrete Empathy to create cultures of psychological safety, employee engagement, well-being, and innovation.
Learn:
Simple ways to signal understanding and empathy across differences and distance
Rules of thumb to avoid misunderstanding, ambiguity, and conflict
Tools to foster innovation and create lasting relationships both within your credit union and with members
We hope you’ll join us for this inspiring keynote on Wednesday, 24 July, 2024, at the World Credit Union Conference in Boston! Secure your spot to the largest global credit union conference of the year and unlock the potential of Concrete Empathy.

body:

View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Webinar:
'
 Emotion Labor '
Presenters: Kris Acheson-Clair and Annette Benson
 
*Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing - use code
 
JAN2024
 
 
 
 
 
January 10th, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
 
In this 90-minute session, Kris and Annette will give insight as to how the theory of emotion labor plays out in the workplace, especially in education; how supervisors can use knowledge of this theory to create an inclusive environment; how faculty and staff can avoid burnout from emotion labor through their healthy responses to it; and why the theory of emotion labor might have shortcomings for some populations. Along the way, participants will be given the opportunity to examine their own experiences with emotion labor and reflect on their own more and less effective strategies for managing emotion labor. Participants might be interested in reading 
The Burnout Spiral: The Emotion Labor of Five Rural U.S. Foreign Language Teachers
 
 
and/or listen to this 
 
podcast
 
on emotion labor in preparation for the webinar; however, it is not required in order to fully benefit from the webinar.
 
Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing - use code
 
JAN2024
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Kris Acheson-Clair
Formerly Georgia State University faculty and Fulbright Scholar to Honduras, Kris is a well-published scholar on intercultural competence, transformative learning theory, emotion labor, and assessment. Kris currently serves as director of Purdue University’s Center for Intercultural Learning, Mentorship, Assessment, and Research (CILMAR). Under her leadership, CILMAR works with the university’s faculty and staff both to put intercultural learning at the heart of study abroad and virtual exchange programs and to embed intercultural learning across the curriculum and student life in order to reach the entire campus. Kris and CILMAR also serve the field of international education by creating scalable experiential and reflective teaching materials, producing cutting-edge scholarship, offering professional development opportunities, and connecting people and resources in the Intercultural Learning Hub (
hubicl.org
).
 
 
 
 
Annette Benson
Since 2003, Annette Benson has served in a variety of administrative roles at Purdue University, including oversight of an ESOL program, HR training in diversity and inclusion, creation of integration and intercultural learning programs, management of the Intercultural Learning Hub, and public relations for the burgeoning CILMAR. Annette holds a Master of Science degree in strategic communication from Purdue’s Brian Lamb School of Communication. She comments that one of the kindest things a supervisor ever did for her was to discuss emotion labor with her.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register

Presenters: Kris Acheson-Clair and Annette Benson
 
*Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing - use code
 
JAN2024
 
 
 
 
 
January 10th, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In this 90-minute session, Kris and Annette will give insight as to how the theory of emotion labor plays out in the workplace, especially in education; how supervisors can use knowledge of this theory to create an inclusive environment; how faculty and staff can avoid burnout from emotion labor through their healthy responses to it; and why the theory of emotion labor might have shortcomings for some populations. Along the way, participants will be given the opportunity to examine their own experiences with emotion labor and reflect on their own more and less effective strategies for managing emotion labor. Participants might be interested in reading 
The Burnout Spiral: The Emotion Labor of Five Rural U.S. Foreign Language Teachers
 
 
and/or listen to this 
 
podcast
 
on emotion labor in preparation for the webinar; however, it is not required in order to fully benefit from the webinar.
 
Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing - use code
 
JAN2024
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenters
Kris Acheson-Clair
Formerly Georgia State University faculty and Fulbright Scholar to Honduras, Kris is a well-published scholar on intercultural competence, transformative learning theory, emotion labor, and assessment. Kris currently serves as director of Purdue University’s Center for Intercultural Learning, Mentorship, Assessment, and Research (CILMAR). Under her leadership, CILMAR works with the university’s faculty and staff both to put intercultural learning at the heart of study abroad and virtual exchange programs and to embed intercultural learning across the curriculum and student life in order to reach the entire campus. Kris and CILMAR also serve the field of international education by creating scalable experiential and reflective teaching materials, producing cutting-edge scholarship, offering professional development opportunities, and connecting people and resources in the Intercultural Learning Hub (
hubicl.org
).
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenters
Kris Acheson-Clair
Formerly Georgia State University faculty and Fulbright Scholar to Honduras, Kris is a well-published scholar on intercultural competence, transformative learning theory, emotion labor, and assessment. Kris currently serves as director of Purdue University’s Center for Intercultural Learning, Mentorship, Assessment, and Research (CILMAR). Under her leadership, CILMAR works with the university’s faculty and staff both to put intercultural learning at the heart of study abroad and virtual exchange programs and to embed intercultural learning across the curriculum and student life in order to reach the entire campus. Kris and CILMAR also serve the field of international education by creating scalable experiential and reflective teaching materials, producing cutting-edge scholarship, offering professional development opportunities, and connecting people and resources in the Intercultural Learning Hub (
hubicl.org
).
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenters
Annette Benson
Since 2003, Annette Benson has served in a variety of administrative roles at Purdue University, including oversight of an ESOL program, HR training in diversity and inclusion, creation of integration and intercultural learning programs, management of the Intercultural Learning Hub, and public relations for the burgeoning CILMAR. Annette holds a Master of Science degree in strategic communication from Purdue’s Brian Lamb School of Communication. She comments that one of the kindest things a supervisor ever did for her was to discuss emotion labor with her.

Annette holds a Master of Science degree in strategic communication from Purdue’s Brian Lamb School of Communication. She comments that one of the kindest things a supervisor ever did for her was to discuss emotion labor with her.

The Global Credit Union Podcast - Episode 32: How World Council Expanded the Relevance of Credit Unions in 2023
We wrap up 2023 by taking a look back at how World Council of Credit Unions succeeded this year in making credit unions more relevant in key strategic areas, such as climate resilience, digitalization and the financial inclusion of migrants, refugees, women and youth on 
Episode 32 of The Global Credit Union Podcast
. 
Our professionals also talk about how World Council put on a record-setting 2023 World Credit Union Conference, expanded our membership base and scored major advocacy victories on behalf of our members. Plus, we look ahead to what should be another promising year in 2024.

subject: Calendly Product Update — 2023 Best-of List
body:
You don't often get email from product-feedback@send.calendly.com. 
Learn why this is important
Explore these end-of-year updates from Calendly.
͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ 
Hi Grace,
This is Jeff from 
Calendly
, sharing our end-of-year product update of the most popular things we launched! Before I start, I want to thank each of you for not only being amazing Calendly customers, but also the kind suggestions you’ve shared over the past year. It’s 
messages like these
 that inspire us!
Updated Design
We’ve always believed a 
clean, simple-to-use design
 sets many scheduling tools apart. However, we can always learn more about “user experience” by listening to you all.
After dozens of customer interviews, we launched a refreshed Calendly with a convenient sidebar for navigation, more intuitive Event Type editing, and better Availability settings — while still offering the powerful scheduling capabilities you depend on.
Speaking of 
Event Types
, long-time users know this is our system for allowing you to make available different blocks of times for your invitees: 30-minute Video Call, 15-Minute Quick Phone Call, 45-Minute In-Person Meeting. (Multiple event types require an 
upgrade to a paid subscription plan
.) 
Event Types got even better this year with some updates including the ability to 
customize your settings before you share your link
. Now, there’s less need to create a whole new event type to update settings (e.g., duration, location) for a quick, one-off change. 
Try Out the New UI
New Availability Setting: Global Holidays
“Just in time for the holi…” We have customers all over the world, so I try to be careful and not assume it’s the holiday season for you! But, if you do observe holidays, you’ll really love our 
new holidays settings
 — all year long.
Our default Holidays feature automatically blocks event types on country-specific holidays, providing an easy way to respect cultural and personal commitments. Go to your Availability settings (bottom left-hand section of the navigation), and you’ll now find a new Holidays tab to get started.
While you’re in your 
Availability settings
, ensure you still like your “default hours” — or even think about adding another schedule. For example, my default hours for meetings are 9:00 to 5:00 Monday through Friday, but I have a special vacation schedule I can turn on to allow for a meeting on Thursdays. 
Try Holidays
Improved Collective and Round Robin Event Types
I love collaborative scheduling, so this is one of my favorite updates of the year!
Hundreds of teams use our 
collaborative scheduling features
 to schedule better together as coworkers: 
Distribute meeting opportunities with available teammates such as sales or customer-success professionals (
Round Robin
 feature)
Team up with a coworker (hiring manager plus recruiter) to encourage a job candidate to join your company (
Collective
 feature)
But you all wanted more — and we’re giving it to you: 
Collective 
plus
 Round Robin
.
Available on the 
Teams and Enterprise subscription plans
, you can now mix and match Collective and Round Robin capabilities to easily get a combination of teammates scheduled. For example, you can improve: 
Product demos to prospects
: Set up an event type with an account executive plus one of five rotating sales engineers
Panel interviews
: Pair a hiring manager with one of three rotating team leaders plus one of four rotating peers interviewers
New-customer onboarding calls
: Include a sales manager who closed the deal plus their assigned customer success manager and one of four rotating technical implementation specialists
Try Collective and Round Robin
Routing Improvements
Have you always wanted to 
add scheduling to your website
 like so many companies did in 2023, yet you’ve yearned for more control over who could book a meeting? And once the customer or recruit booked a meeting, you wished it would route to the right teammate?
That’s where 
Routing
 comes in: Now, you can qualify people by asking questions before they book a time, and then route them to the correct person on your team.
Our marketing and sales customers inspired us to improve Routing by building integrations with their existing tools: 
Integrate Calendly Routing with your 
HubSpot
, 
Marketo
, or 
Pardot
 third-party forms (available on our 
Teams plan
)
Use our own 
Routing forms
 (
Teams plan
) – if you don’t have a third-party form
Conduct Salesforce CRM lookup
 and account matching (
Enterprise plan
)
Examine 
Routing Analytics
 to track meeting conversion rates and see how forms perform
Sync data back to your marketing-automation system such as Marketo
 to power retargeting campaigns (e.g., if someone fills out a form, but doesn’t book a meeting, trigger an email) (
Teams plan
)
Get Routing
Analytics Improvements
We aimed our first introduction of 
Analytics
 at account administrators seeking to understand scheduling trends — across their team. Now, each person on your team can view their own meeting data in their 
personal Analytics Dashboard
. 
Available on the 
Standard subscription plan
, your personal Analytics Dashboard allows you to fine-tune scheduling with 
insights
 like popular meeting times, top event types, total completed events, and more. 
Learn More
Account-Admin Tool Updates
Have you thanked your account administrator lately? As our thank-you, we’ve recently released a bevy of updates to make their lives easier: 
Admin Dashboard
: See organization-wide activity — pending invites, missing calendar and video conferencing connections, and key event stats — in one central location. (Available on the 
Standard subscription plan
)
User Profiles
: Review teammate-specific details, such as their calendar and video integrations, availability, and quick links to their event types, by clicking on a user’s avatar. (
Standard plan
)
Group Admin Improvements
: Group Admins can now invite teammates, create Managed Events, and view meeting data in the Analytics Dashboard for their Calendly Groups. (
Teams plan
)
Top Webinars From 2023
Thousands of you attended our webinars this year for 
getting started
, using 
Calendly as a team
, and learning more about best practices in your role. These were our most popular webinars in 2023:
Sales & Marketing teams: 
How to Fill Pipeline During Economic Uncertainty
 
Customer Success and Support teams: 
Build a Better Journey for Retention: Pro Tips for CS Teams
Recruiting teams: 
Hire Faster with Calendly: Pro Tips for Recruiters
Education teams: 
How Dartmouth Supports Student Wellbeing with Calendly
Financial Services teams: 
How Financial Services Companies Drive Revenue with Calendly
 
CRM Improvements
Salesforce
: One of our most popular integrations is with Salesforce, as it allows sales teams to sync meeting data into this popular CRM. We improved the integration this year by allowing admins to now 
sync data to Salesforce by groups
 (e.g., a Sales Group), sync profile links and Calendly Managed Event links to Salesforce, and sync no-show status to the CRM. (Available on our 
Enterprise plan
)
Dynamics
: Our Microsoft-loving customers spoke up and asked for an integration with Microsoft’s CRM: Dynamics. And of course we had to deliver. With our Microsoft Dynamics 365 integration, when Calendly meetings are scheduled, your invitee information and scheduled meeting information is automatically added (or updated) in your records. (Available on our 
Enterprise plan
) 
Other Popular Integrations
Linktree
: Easily add your Calendly to this service used by millions of social influencers and more.
Gong
: Gong released its outbound-sales engagement platform this year, and chose Calendly as a scheduling integration.
Zapier
: Don’t see an integration you like? Zapier has probably made it possible for you. 
View Integrations
Domain Control
In 2023, we launched 
Domain Control
 for account admins and IT departments looking to guide employees signing up for Calendly to join their primary accounts, where team scheduling features and account-wide integrations (e.g., Managed Events, Salesforce, etc.) are set up and ready to go. 
Learn More
Updated 
Browser Extensions
 and 
Mobile Apps
Join me and many others, and make it easier to use Calendly wherever you are with our 
mobile apps
 and 
browser extensions
.
Our tools are now better at group collaboration with shared event type avatars and meeting polls, faster at serving up exactly what you’re looking for with event type search, more flexible with one-off meetings, and more embedded in your other tools from Google Calendar to Gong. 
Calendly Access Update
Do you allowlist Calendly IPs? If so, you’ll want to read more about an 
upcoming change.
 
Additional Popular Resources
Report: 
Total Economic Impact of Calendly by Forrester Research
 
Report: 
State of Scheduling Report
 
Customer Stories
Oh my, there was so much to write about this year! Next year’s product-launch list is going to be even greater. Stay tuned! And thank you again for all of your input and support! 
Happy 2024,
Jeff Hardison
Head of Product Marketing @ Calendly
P.S. And one more thing! 
Here’s how to find how many meetings
 you created this year with Calendly. Share your end-of-year results with us in the comments. 
Need help?
  
Help Center
 ‌ | ‌ 
Pricing & FAQs
 ‌ | ‌ 
Contact Us
 
More than a scheduling link.
 
 
 
 
 
115 E. Main Street, Suite A1B, Buford, GA 30518
www.calendly.com
 ‌ | ‌

View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
THIS WEBINAR WILL BE RESCHEDULED
We apologize for the last minute change but due to some 
unforeseen
 circumstances we will need to cancel today's webinar. Please be on the look out for a new date. 
'
Resilience
 and Collective Care: Lessons From Black Communities '
Your Presenter:
Danice L. Brown, Ph.D,
 
Professor of Counseling Psychology, Towson University
 
 
 
 
 
 
December 13, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
 
Experiences of racial stress create daily and ongoing challenges for Black communities. As society continues to navigate the realities of systemic racism, Black communities have found ways to cultivate resilience through the use of collective care strategies. This webinar will focus specifically on how Black communities utilize collective care in their resilience. We will discuss the use of culturally specific forms of protection, healing, and social support that have contributed to resilience among Black youth and adults. Additionally, the importance of allyship in creating a sense of belonging and support outside of Black communities will be addressed.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenter
Danice Brown, Ph.D.
Dr. Danice Brown is currently a Professor in the Counseling Psychology Graduate Program at Towson University where she serves as the Coordinator of Clinical Training. Dr. Brown also has a small therapy private practice. She received her Ph.D. in Counseling Psychology from The Ohio State University in 2008. Dr. Brown has built a strong program of research focused on examining African American resiliency, racial socialization, the intersectional socialization experiences of Black women, and multicultural issues in counseling.

Dr. Brown also has a small therapy private practice. She received her Ph.D. in Counseling Psychology from The Ohio State University in 2008. Dr. Brown has built a strong program of research focused on examining African American resiliency, racial socialization, the intersectional socialization experiences of Black women, and multicultural issues in counseling.

subject: Inclusion and Belonging Sessions for CSAA's Executive Leadership Team
body:
Hello Grace,
 
I hope you're doing great. I am emailing to discuss inclusion and belonging learning and workshop sessions for CSAA Insurance Group's Enterprise Leadership Team (ELT) in 2024. 
 
This year, the ELT underwent a year-long inclusion and belonging learning path, which included six-month IDI-based coaching and quarterly sessions on equity and leadership, systems thinking, and intercultural conflict style. We want to keep this momentum going and support the ELT in their comfort in advocating and advancing equity and inclusion through discourse, workshops, and training. 
 
Can we schedule a meeting to discuss this further? We would like to hear your ideas before we meet so that we can use our time together for deeper discussion and strategy. 
 
If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to reach out. We're excited to hear from you.
 
Warmly, 
 
MeShawn

subject: Unlocking Potential: The Power of a Comprehensive CEO Evaluation Approach
body:
You don't often get email from communications@woccu.org. 
Learn why this is important
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
Unlocking Potential: The Power of a Comprehensive CEO Evaluation Approach
Tuesday, December 12, 2023, 10:00 a.m. US Central Standard Time (CST)
Esta sesión también estará disponible en español y portugu
é
s. 
In today's fast-paced financial landscape, credit union success hinges on strong leadership. Ensure your CEO's performance consistently aligns with the credit union's mission, vision, values, and strategic objectives through a well-structured evaluation process. By defining clear performance metrics and expectations, the evaluation process provides actionable insights and valuable feedback for the CEO to follow while fostering a culture of accountability and transparency. Embrace the transformative power of the CEO evaluation approach to optimize leadership potential, foster excellence, and drive your credit union towards sustained growth and success.
Participant takeaways include:
Participants will learn the importance of a rigorous and objective evaluation process.
Participants will explore the key questions that shape the CEO evaluation process.
Participants will understand the common pain points in CEO evaluations.
This 60-minute workshop-webinar is presented by:
Miranda Flury, President, Hawkeye Strategies, Canada
 
 
NEW
 
–
 
World Council will be offering CPE Credits for this webinar! Participants must be present for the full session to receive credit. Attendance will be recorded. There is no fee to attend!
Participants will earn 1.0 CPE Credit.
Field of Study:
 
Business Management & Organization
Additional Information
Prerequisites
: None
Who Should Attend:
 
Board Directors and CEOs
Advance Preparation:
 None Required.
Program Level:
 Overview
Delivery Method:
 Group Internet Based

subject: Eight Days Left to Submit Your GWLN Scholarship Application
body:
You don't often get email from cuwomen@woccu.org. 
Learn why this is important
Read this in your browser.
Eight Days Left to Submit Your GWLN Scholarship Application
 
 
The deadline for the Global Women’s Leadership Network (GWLN) 2024 scholarship is fast approaching — December 15, 2023!
 
There are eight (8) days left to apply for the chance to attend career building events around the world.
 
The GWLN 2024 scholarship will award up to four (4) winners the opportunity to attend the World Credit Union Conference (WCUC) in Boston, USA from July 21-24, 2024 for five (5) full days of learning, networking and exchange with the heart of the credit union movement. 
 
The 2024 scholarships include airfare, hotel and registration fees for the awarded event.
 
To apply for the GWLN 2024 scholarship, please visit 
cuwomen.org
.
 
Global Women’s Leadership Network
 connects, inspires, and empowers women with the opportunities and resources to make a measurable difference …  in the lives of each other, in the lives of credit union members and in their communities.
 
 
The Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions is the
 
partner organization to the World Council, established to advance the shared vision of expanding financial inclusion through a vibrant and growing global credit union system.
 
Join us on a global journey to transform a billion lives worldwide using credit unions. Visit 
www.doglobalgood.org
 to start your journey today.

P.O. Box 2982 • Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA •

subject: Calendly Product Update –  November 2023
body:
Featuring Routing Analytics, Forrester Research's study on Calendly, Edge Extension and more.
͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ 
Hi Grace,
This is Jeff from 
Calendly
 with some product updates, resources, and tips to share to make scheduling easier and more productive for our sales, marketing, and customer success customers.
How Many People Schedule 
Meetings From Your Forms?
Some of our most successful customers 
add scheduling capabilities to their website
. Yet, you know what holds some others back? They worry just anyone will find their Calendly, and book a time without qualifying them! That’s what I love about our 
Routing features
, as they allow you to ask invitees questions before they can book time with you and your team. 
Available on the Teams subscription plan and above, 
Routing
 is now improved with Routing Analytics that reveal how your routing forms perform with candidates, clients, and potential customers. Within your 
Calendly Analytics
, you can now see reports on conversion rates and track scheduling trends coming from your Calendly, HubSpot, Marketo, or Pardot forms. Note: Only account admins and owners can 
check out routing analytics
. 
Get Routing Analytics
Survey: How Do You Organize 
Your Professional Contacts?
Getting more organized is often a priority as we start a new year. When it comes to managing your professional contacts (candidates, clients, and customer leads), we’d love to learn more about how you currently keep track of these relationships. Let us know by taking this 
3-minute survey
! 
Take the Survey
What Forrester Research Found 
When They Studied Calendly
If you haven’t checked out 
Forrester Research’s study on Calendly
 — which includes interviews with customers DocuSign, Atlassian, GardaWorld, and Semrush — you can grab it 
here
.
Personally, I’ve always enjoyed talking to research analyst firms like Forrester, because they work with thousands of customers who want advice on which tech products to buy. And, as a Calendly employee, they can give me a “voice of the customer” reality check when I need one! Here are a few things Forrester heard from Calendly’s customers:
“One of the pain points was trying to schedule with external clients while keeping their data safely secured. Calendly really supports their existing workflows. I don’t think we have any other tools that do that level of advanced extra routing for a team.” - Atlassian’s Global Collaboration Specialist
“First [added value is] connectivity, [then] ease of access to our calendar so that there was a way that team members could manage their tasks. Another added value is consistency, as we’re delivering our engagement consistently to optimize customer and employee experience along with ease and flexibility.” DocuSign’s VP of Success at Scale
“We can definitely say that when a sales rep is involved and has a meeting on the calendar for a renewal, the chances of expansion go up and Calendly definitely plays a part in that.” - Semrush’s Sales Project Manager
“A couple of years ago, we were at 21 days [in our recruiting process], and then we got it down to 17 days. [Now it is] about 15 and a half days from application to when they’re earning a paycheck.” - GardaWorld’s Senior Director of Talent Acquisition
That’s just a sample of what these customers have to say in the report. 
Feel free to download it
, or read the 
blog post
 if you prefer. 
Get the Report
An Even Edgier Extension
Have you added our 
browser extensions
 yet to make your life easier? Join customer Trevor Robinson and thousands of others who use it to quickly grab their scheduling link in their email tool, use our LinkedIn integration, and more!
And, Microsoft Edge users, Calendly’s extension is easier to find than ever before — no more detours to the Chrome Web Store. Find us with all your other 
Edge Add-ons here
. If you haven’t had the chance to try our extension yet, it grants you one-click access to Calendly from anywhere on the web, or even from the 
Outlook
 app if that’s where you spend most of your day.
We’re also available on 
Chrome
 and 
Firefox
, but if there’s a different browser or application you’d like to see us tackle next, 
reply
 to let us know. 
Get the Edge Extension
Salesforce Integration Update
If you take advantage of the 
no-show status feature
 in Calendly to track meeting attendees, those updates can now sync to Salesforce automatically. This feature requires the 
latest version of the Salesforce integration package (2.6)
 and manual enablement of the no-show flow template in Salesforce. 
Learn More
Additional Resources

How to Use Calendly to Close More Deals
 
Report: 
Total Economic Impact of Calendly by Forrester Research
 
Webinar: 
Getting Started with Calendly
 
Webinar: 
How Teams Use Calendly
 
Thanks for reading, 
Jeff Hardison
Head of Product Marketing @ Calendly

body:

 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
Unlocking Potential: The Power of a Comprehensive CEO Evaluation Approach
Tuesday, December 12, 2023, 10:00 a.m. US Central Standard Time (CST)
Esta sesión también estará disponible en español y portugu
é
s. 
In today's fast-paced financial landscape, credit union success hinges on strong leadership. Ensure your CEO's performance consistently aligns with the credit union's mission, vision, values, and strategic objectives through a well-structured evaluation process. By defining clear performance metrics and expectations, the evaluation process provides actionable insights and valuable feedback for the CEO to follow while fostering a culture of accountability and transparency. Embrace the transformative power of the CEO evaluation approach to optimize leadership potential, foster excellence, and drive your credit union towards sustained growth and success.
Participant takeaways include:
Participants will learn the importance of a rigorous and objective evaluation process.
Participants will explore the key questions that shape the CEO evaluation process.
Participants will understand the common pain points in CEO evaluations.
This 60-minute workshop-webinar is presented by:
Miranda Flury, President, Hawkeye Strategies, Canada

View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Dear Grace,
We cannot wait to see you (virtually) at our annual business meeting 
December 14, 2023 4:30pmPT/6:30pm CT/7:30pm ET
We will share important updates from the board (including new board nominees) and have the opportunity to catch up with one another. Please register below.  Also, scroll down to register for the last webinar of the year happening the day before our meeting. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Register for meeting! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Webinar:
'
Resilience
 and Collective Care: Lessons From Black Communities '
Presenter: D
anice L. Brown, Ph.D,
 
Professor of Counseling Psychology, Towson University
 
 
*Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing - use code
 
DEC13_WEB
 
 
 
 
 
December 13, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
 
Experiences of racial stress create daily and ongoing challenges for Black communities. As society continues to navigate the realities of systemic racism, Black communities have found ways to cultivate resilience through the use of collective care strategies. This webinar will focus specifically on how Black communities utilize collective care in their resilience. We will discuss the use of culturally specific forms of protection, healing, and social support that have contributed to resilience among Black youth and adults. Additionally, the importance of allyship in creating a sense of belonging and support outside of Black communities will be addressed.
 
Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing - use code
 
DEC13_WEB
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenter
Danice Brown, Ph.D.
Dr. Danice Brown is currently a Professor in the Counseling Psychology Graduate Program at Towson University where she serves as the Coordinator of Clinical Training. Dr. Brown also has a small therapy private practice. She received her Ph.D. in Counseling Psychology from The Ohio State University in 2008. Dr. Brown has built a strong program of research focused on examining African American resiliency, racial socialization, the intersectional socialization experiences of Black women, and multicultural issues in counseling.
 
 
 
About Your Presenter
Danice Brown, Ph.D.
Dr. Danice Brown is currently a Professor in the Counseling Psychology Graduate Program at Towson University where she serves as the Coordinator of Clinical Training. Dr. Brown also has a small therapy private practice. She received her Ph.D. in Counseling Psychology from The Ohio State University in 2008. Dr. Brown has built a strong program of research focused on examining African American resiliency, racial socialization, the intersectional socialization experiences of Black women, and multicultural issues in counseling.

subject: Digital Transformation - It's Not an IT Thing
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
Digital Transformation - It's Not an IT Thing
Wednesday, November 29, 2023 - 10:00 a.m. U.S. Central Standard Time (CST)
Shahani Perera
Digital transformation does not necessarily mean quickly replacing all your technology solutions and business processes simultaneously. Instead, it’s an evolution over time. It’s not enough for a company’s leaders to champion digital transformation. Digital transformation success is dependent on every department and employee within a company adjusting their mindset.
In this World Council virtual event, attendees will learn the three key areas where they can adjust the way they approach work to prime their departments and organizations as a whole for success in Digital Transformation.
This virtual event will feature a presentation from:
Shahani Perera
, SVP Digital Transformation, Innovation Federal Credit Union (Canada)

subject: Growing Membership at WOCCU and Across Our Global Movement
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
The Global Credit Union Podcast - Episode 31: Growing Membership at WOCCU and Across Our Global Movement 
Thom Belekevich, World Council of Credit Unions’ (WOCCU) Director of Member Services, helped open the door of WOCCU membership to more credit union associations and even some individual credit unions for the first time in 2023. He joins 
Episode 31 of the Global Credit Union Podcast
 to discuss the expansion of our membership categories, the types of organizations it opens up eligibility to and why it should enrich WOCCU's diversity even more moving forward. 
Thom also led the data collection for WOCCU's 2022 Statistical Report, which shows the global credit union movement is now more than 400 million members strong. He explains where that growth is occurring, the common denominators among the countries seeing those gains and how COVID-19 impacted the ability of some countries to continue capturing quality credit union data.
                                       
                                    
You can find past episodes of The Global Credit Union Podcast by
 
clicking here
. To suggest a topic or guest for a future episode, contact Greg Neumann, World Council Director of Communications, at
 
gneumann@woccu.org
.

subject: Goalmakers 2023 Conference - 2023 Global Hero announced!
body:
You don't often get email from events@globalwa.org. 
Learn why this is important
GOALMAKERS ANNUAL CONFERENCE 2023
November 30 + December 7
 
Global Hero | Speakers | Agenda | Exhibitor Tabling
 
2023 Global Hero
Since 2011 Global Washington’s Board of Directors bestows a Global Hero award each year to an individual who has made a significant contribution to the global development community in Washington state. This is considered a life-time achievement award. This award is given to one person in our GlobalWA community who has shown years of dedication to improving lives in low- and middle-income countries. 
 
This year we are very excited to announce that Pat Garcia-Gonzalez, Chief Executive Officer of The Max Foundation, will be recognized as the 2023 Global Hero.
 
We invite you to join us on Dec. 7th when we honor Pat in 
receiving
 this award. Help us celebrate her amazing achievements!
2023 Global Hero: Pat Garcia-Gonzalez, Chief Executive Officer of The Max Foundation
“Your extraordinary dedication to cancer survivors and overall health equity is a shining light and inspiration to others. The Max Foundation has thrived under your leadership and determination to reach those in need with practical approaches and cutting-edge innovation,” stated Kristen Dailey, Executive Director of GlobalWA.
 
Read more about this year's award »
See past year's Global Heroes »
 
Speakers Announced
We have added new speakers!  As with each year, our Goalmakers 2023 
Conference
 will be filled with incredible knowledge, wisdom, and expertise from global development leaders and experts. We hope you can join us!
 
Visit our Speakers page to find out more » 
 
Goalmakers 2023 Agenda
The theme of our conference this year is 
Advancing Transformative Philanthropy
. 
Examples to be discussed at the conference include U.S. based foundations that support community-based organizations in a low- or middle-income countries, U.S. NGOs that subcontract to other organizations, and giving circles that give to grassroots organizations outside the U.S.
We will unpack the inherent power dynamics between funder and recipient and then apply our co-creation process to determine better, more equitable relationships.  Do you have your ticket yet?
 
Goalmakers 2023 Agenda »

subject: GWLN Opens Annual Scholarships for Women Leaders
body:
Read this in your browser.
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
2023-11-16
GWLN Opens Annual Scholarships for Women Leaders
GWLN is now accepting scholarship applications from credit union women
 
2023 Scholars attending WCUC 2023 in Vancouver, CA
 
Attendees at the GWLN Forum at 2023 WCUC
  
MADISON, Wis. — The Global Women’s Leadership Network (GWLN), an initiative of the Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions (WFCU), opened the annual scholarship on November 15, offering learning opportunities during 2024 for women in the credit union space to advance leadership skills.
The GWLN 2024 scholarship will award up to four (4) winners the opportunity to attend the 
World Credit Union Conference (WCUC)
 
in Boston, MA, USA from July 21-24 to learn, network and engage with the largest gathering of credit union professionals in the world
. The GWLN scholarship includes airfare, hotel and registration fees for 2024 WCUC.
Since 2009, GWLN has awarded 
100 scholarships
 to women leaders in the credit union community from over 30 countries. These annual awards recognize individuals who have demonstrated leadership and exemplify a commitment to improving lives through financial cooperatives.
Scholars will connect with the heart of the global credit union movement during five (5) full days of learning, networking and exchange. The 2024 scholars will participate in all GWLN events, connect with scholarship supporters, GWLN members and Sister Society leaders while engaging with conference attendees throughout WCUC. Focusing on professional development, scholars evolve through interactive dialogue sessions, expanding their knowledge and growing professional relationships at the conference.
“I was drawn to GWLN because of its mission to create a more equitable world, where women have equal access to opportunities and resources as their male counterparts. As someone who is passionate about women's leadership and gender equity, GWLN is offering a meaningful and impactful way for me to get involved and make a difference,” said Naddian Abraham-Damier, a 2023 scholar, who attended the World Credit Union Conference in Vancouver, Canada.
Scholarships are made possible through funding from GWLN memberships and industry champion sponsorships. In 2023, sponsors included 
Co-op Solutions
, 
TruStage
, 
Origence
, 
PSCU
 and the Susan Adams Scholarship Fund which was established in honor of former Entrust Financial Credit Union CEO Susan Adams supported by 
One AZ Credit Union
.
“GWLN will be celebrating 15 years in 2024, and it’s an exciting time for the network. The annual scholarship program is essential to our work for women’s advancement to leadership in our global movement. We have seen the tremendous impact the scholars have made for women in their credit unions and communities. We must continue our collective efforts in growing the program,” said Lena Giakoumopoulos, GWLN Director.
The scholarship portal will close on December 15, 2023. Scholarship winners will be announced in January 2024.
To learn more about the GWLN scholarship, please visit 
CUWomen.org
.
Global Women’s Leadership Network connects, inspires, , and empowers women with the opportunities and resources to make a measurable difference …  in the lives of each other, in the lives of credit union members and in their communities. 
To learn more about GWLN, visit 
CUWomen.org
.
The Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions is the
 
partner organization to the World Council, established to advance the shared vision of expanding financial inclusion through a vibrant and growing global credit union system.
 
Join us on a global journey to transform a billion lives worldwide using credit unions. Visit 
www.doglobalgood.org
 to start your journey today.

subject: Growing Membership at WOCCU and Across Our Global Movement
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
The Global Credit Union Podcast - Episode 31: Growing Membership at WOCCU and Across Our Global Movement 
Thom Belekevich, World Council of Credit Unions’ (WOCCU) Director of Member Services, helped open the door of WOCCU membership to more credit union associations and even some individual credit unions for the first time in 2023. He joins 
Episode 31 of the Global Credit Union Podcast
 to discuss the expansion of our membership categories, the types of organizations it opens up eligibility to and why it should enrich WOCCU's diversity even more moving forward. 
Thom also led the data collection for WOCCU's 2022 Statistical Report, which shows the global credit union movement is now more than 400 million members strong. He explains where that growth is occurring, the common denominators among the countries seeing those gains and how COVID-19 impacted the ability of some countries to continue capturing quality credit union data.

subject: SIETAR USA Membership Update
body:
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
MEMBERSHIP UPDATE
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Dear Grace,
Thank you for your membership with SIETAR USA! As we wrap up 2023 we wanted to share some important updates with you. Next month, we will host our final webinar of 2023 as well as our annual business meeting. 
SAVE THE DATE(s)! 
December 13th Wednesday Webinar @ 11:30am EST
 
Resilience and Collective Care: Lessons from Black Communities presented by 
Danice L. Brown, Ph.D,
 
Professor of Counseling Psychology, Towson University
 
              
Experiences of racial stress create daily and ongoing challenges for Black communities. As society continues to navigate the realities of systemic racism, Black communities have found ways to cultivate resilience through the use of collective care strategies. This webinar will focus specifically on how Black communities utilize collective care in their resilience. We will discuss the use of culturally specific forms of protection, healing, and social support that have contributed to resilience among Black youth and adults. Additionally, the importance of allyship in creating a sense of belonging and support outside of Black communities will be addressed.
  Registration opening soon!
December 14th Annual Business Meeting @ 6:30pm CST 
We hope to see you all at our virtual annual business meeting next month. More information will be shared in the coming weeks including agenda, zoom link and more.
Administrative Officer Update
This summer our amazing Administrative Officer, Karen Fouts has stepped down from her role. While she will no longer support SIETAR USA as the administrative officer, we are fortunate enough to have her still very much involved as she is leading the 2024 Virtual Conference planning. Please join us in thanking Karen for all she has done for SIETAR USA members. In August, we welcomed Christina Benavides into the role as our new Administrative Officer. You can still contact 
info@sietarusa.org 
for any questions or support. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
IN MEMORIAM 
SIETAR USA honors the lives of Dr. BeEtta Stoney and Richard W. Brislin.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Dr. BeEtta Stoney  
It is with heavy hearts that we share the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. BeEtta Stoney, best known as Be, who died on September 5, 2023 in Manhattan.  
Be brought a unique and dynamic perspective to our SIETAR USA community, and we are a better organization today for her contributions. Be was a Coach and Associate Professor at Kansas State University for 24 years, and most recently served as their Interim Chief Diversity and Inclusion Officer. 
Be proved to be an incredible team player, a skill she exemplified as a Hall of Fame basketball player at University of Texas, El Paso where she earned her bachelor’s degree in secondary education - special education/health education and a master’s degree in kinesiology. She also earned a doctorate in special education/multicultural education from the University of Texas, Austin. Be was inducted into the UTEP Athletics Hall of Fame in 2010 and ranks third all-time in UTEP career points with 1,249.  
I remember Be most as an advocate for students and mentor. In 2015, I was fortunate to see Be co-present "Mentoring Black Fraternities: The Modern Day Intellectual Talented Tenth”, with five of her students from K-State at the Mentoring Institute at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque, New Mexico. It was incredible to witness the love and admiration her students had for her and her mentorship. 
She was an incredible friend and mentor, and she will be missed by all of the lives she touched while she was with us. Our thoughts are with her family and those closest to her at this time. 
Tamara Thorpe 
A Reflection from 
Patricia Malidor Coleman 
Once upon a time two women met at a SIETAR USA conference. Two brown women from two different continents: two worlds apart, yet our differences are the reason why we connected deeply in a setting where building cultural differences builds relationships with trust and respect.   
Be Stoney was not sure if SIETAR USA was the organization was for her. She came and found a way to get involved at first in our silent auction to raise funds for students and those new to our industry to ease into the intercultural and global diversity field. This purpose resonated with her.  
 
It was through planning, setting and hosting this great event that Be and I exchanged on many of our commonalities: curiosity in cultures, creating a safe space to be authentic and have a true sense of belonging, leadership skills of women of color in sports, basketball, coaching, teaching.  We both agreed that she was at the right place not only to learn but also to give of herself.  
Later, Be worked on several committees and with our Board of Directors during my presidency at SIETAR USA.   
Be was a diamond in disguise that came out to shine as she so naturally does.  
I am honored that God put Be Stoney on the path of SIETAR USA as it is great women like her that brought new bricks to pave our road to stronger D.E.I.B.  A new and lacking perspective that opened the door for shifting perspectives, into the future.
One who has met Be Stoney will never be the same again as she touched many minds and hearts with tough and sincere love.  
R.I.P Sister! 
 
 
Richard W. Brislin
 
Richard W. Brislin died on August 24, 2023, at age 78. Another intercultural pioneer has left us. SIETAR USA members are reminded again that we stand on the shoulders of the giants in our field. We have lost a number of those giants with Richard being one of the most recent. A social psychologist, distinguished professor and researcher, he devoted his career to studying the effects of culture on behavior. 
Richard was born May 9, 1945, and spent his early years in New England, high school in Anchorage, AK, college at the University of Washington, University of Guam, and Pennsylvania State University where he earned his Master's and Doctorate. Some might characterize him a Renaissance man because from an early age he approached and embraced a wide swath of life's enjoyment and accomplishments, including becoming an Eagle Scout, acting in high school and college plays, playing as a Bridge Life Master, becoming a self-taught folk and bluegrass multi-instrumentalist and ethnomusicologist in Americana music, and cruising the globe with Rose Ann, his wife of 52 years. In his early years he joined a circus and using an intercultural lens, perceived it to be a very close culture with its own norms, values, and social structure. 
 
Known for his early research in the intercultural field and his writing—he published a wide array of books such as:  
Cross-Cultural Research Methods in Behavioral Science
 (1973); his earliest publication, written with Walt Lonner. 
Cross-Cultural Research: The Role of Culture in Understanding Human Behavior 
(1975) written with Marshall Segal.  
Intercultural Interactions: A Practical Guide
 (1986); a personal favorite in which he used a Culture Assimilator approach to culture general issues, written with Kenneth Cushner, Craig Cherrie and Mahealani Yong. 
The Art of Getting Things Done: A Practical Guide to the Use of Power
 (1991); his book that could purportedly be found on “numerous congressional and corporate bookshelves” and was selected Book of the Month in 1992. 
Understanding Culture’s Influence on Behavior
 (1993); his classic written as a text for courses dealing with culture’s impact on human behavior. 
Working with Cultural Differences: Dealing Effectively with Diversity in the Workplace
 (2008); using a critical incidents approach to illustrate basic psychological processes that play a part in effective—and ineffective—intercultural and interracial relationships in the workplace. 
Those books represent the tip of the iceberg in terms of Richard’s multiple books and numerous articles. He valued his relationships with others and wrote and edited with a number of interculturalists such as Kenneth Cushner, Walt Lonner, Stephen Bochner, Harry Triandis, and Tomoko Yoshida. 
He was working in Washington, DC when SIETAR International moved from Pittsburgh and formed its association with Georgetown University. He became an early, active member presenting at the SIETAR conferences and attending various meetings and events. He felt that SIETAR was designed as a forum for professional educators, trainers, and researchers, and therefore should focus on the needs of the senior people working in the intercultural field. SIETAR has since struggled with balancing the needs of the senior professionals and addressing the needs of students and newcomers to the field. 
Leaving the mainland for Hawaii, Richard led the East-West Center's Culture Learning Institute where he wrote many of his books on cross-cultural understanding. He had a second career in Hawaii with the Shidler College of Business at UH Manoa as a distinguished professor and chair of management and industry relations, where he was awarded the Regents Medal in Teaching and wrote further books on management and surviving in the workplace. He was the recipient of several professional awards and honors and was an invited speaker at universities and conferences across the globe.
