subject: One month from TODAY: SIETAR USA Saturday Seminar
body:
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!' - 9-Sept-2023 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
SATURDAY SEMINAR: 
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: 
One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!'
 
Your Seminar Leader:
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
 
 
 
 
September 9, 2023 @ 12:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
Have 
YOU
 registered yet? This educational event is only one month from TODAY!
Don't miss this Saturday Seminar!  
Jay Cafferata
 will focus on how we unknowingly and unfortunately perpetuate racist ideology, colonialism, oppression, and discrimination in the words we use.  We'll be discussing the breakdown in communication between intercultural and inclusion dialogues. When we think about intercultural, we think international, global or worldwide – but when we think about inclusion, we think local, internal and the workplace. Why are we having these different conversations to the same discourse? What is the breakdown between these two seemingly different sets of vocabulary?
This interactive 4-hour session will include videos, polling, and breakout sessions. Participants are encouraged to join using a device that has a camera and a microphone as well as a secondary device like a phone or computer that allows for multiple windows to be open at the same time for the polling.
Participants will discuss and reflect on:
The words we use to describe others
Historical perspectives on these two lexicons
Global vs Local
The direction of impact: who is studying who?
At the conclusion of the presentation, participants will have:
A greater recognition of how inclusion and intercultural fit together.
The basic awareness of how we present ourselves in an environment or culture that is not necessarily our own.
Strategies to be more aware of where we are as professionals.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Registration Fees
$20 for Students
$45 for current SIETAR USA members in good standing
$65 for non-members
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Student-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Non-Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Your Seminar Leader
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
Mr. Cafferata is a well-known speaker and advocate for issues involving Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging. He considers himself a Social Justice Warrior and has spent decades as an advocate for the Sexual and Gender Minority Community. He has over 20 years of experience working with families of children with special needs. He has a master’s degree in communication studies from University of Nevada, Reno. and an associate degree in Deaf Studies from Western Nevada College. Mr. Cafferata is also a Certified Diversity Executive. He can be reached at 
jay@asltraining.com
.

Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE

Webinar: Navigating the Changing Landscape of Services Marketing in the Credit Union Industry
Time: Wednesday, August 16rh at 10:00 am CT
As credit unions continue to face increased competition and changing consumer preferences, it's more important than ever to have a solid services marketing strategy in place. With new technologies and communication channels constantly emerging, credit unions must adapt and evolve to stay relevant and attract new members. This presentation will provide insights and strategies for credit unions to navigate the changing landscape of services marketing.
In this webinar, participants will learn:
Understanding the Evolving Consumer Landscape
Changes in consumer behavior and preferences 
Impact of technology on consumer expectations
Demographic shifts and the implications for credit unions

View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
WEBINAR: 
'Exploring African Culture'
Your Presenter:
Geremie Sawadago, 
HR Manager, World Bank Group
 
 
 
 
September 13, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
This webinar will explore
 the rich diversity in African cultures and discuss the case for African cultural unity around six shared cultural values, including: 
(1) communication style; (2) individualism/collectivism; (3) power distance; (4) uncertainty avoidance; (5) polychromic use of time; and (6) long term/short term orientation. 
 Participants will further their knowledge, appreciation and understanding of African cultures and learn tips to effectively communicate and interact with Africans in both a professional and personal context. 
 
Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing
 
Use Members Only Webinar Code: MBR_WBNR09
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenter
Geremie Sawadago
Geremie Sawadogo is HR Manager at The World Bank Group in Washington DC.
  
Prior to joining the Bank, Geremie was the Country Director for the US Peace Corps in Benin, and he has also taught education and intercultural communication and directed international education programs at universities and community colleges across the US.
  
Geremie is a published 
author in the areas of intercultural competencies and international education, and he wrote the African cultural assessment tool (AfricanXculture.com) which allows individuals to assess themselves against an African cultural values benchmark.

body:
Are YOU ready to serve? ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Dear SIETAR USA Members and Colleagues,
 
 
 
 
 
The SIETAR USA leadership team values diversity in all its forms and is committed to creating and fostering an inclusive environment for all SIETAR USA members. To that end, we are issuing the 
2023 Call for Nominations for the Board of Directors of SIETAR USA
. We encourage all members of our community to participate in the Board of Directors election process to support our efforts to cultivate a culture that embraces and values diversity, equity, and inclusion. 
You may nominate yourself or another member of the organization. Any candidate for Board positions must meet the following criteria in addition to role-specific requirements listed in each position description:
 
 
 
 
1.
     
Possess a strong background and understanding of intercultural communications and/or fields of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging (DEIB).
 
 
 
 
 
2.
     
Be a member in good standing with SIETAR USA (or willing to become a member).
 
 
 
 
3.
     
Have attended at least one SIETAR USA conference in recent years.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Open Positions
 
There are a total of five (5) board positions open for nominations in 2023:
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
View Open Positions for 2023 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Nominations Process-Details 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
All nominations must be submitted using the form provided (click the 'Submit Nomination' button shown below) NO LATER THAN:
 
Friday, September 1, 2023 
5 PM CST
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Submit Nomination 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
We look forward to your responses to this Call for Nominations and your participation in this process! 
Feel free to contact us with any questions at 
boardleadership@sietarusa.org
 or 
admin@sietarusa.org
.
Thank you for supporting SIETAR USA!

subject: 2023 Global Women’s Leadership Network Empowerment Grant Winners to Increase Financial Access Worldwide
body:
Read this in your browser.
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
2023-08-08
2023 Global Women’s Leadership Network Empowerment Grant Winners to Increase Financial Access Worldwide
GWLN scholars from Kenya, Mongolia each receive $10,000 grants
 
Enkhchimeg Nergui
 
Violet Ndungu
 
Empowerment Grant pitches during the GWLN Forum at the 2023 World Credit Union Conference
MADISON, Wis —
Global Women’s Leadership Network
 is pleased to announce its 2023 Empowerment Grant winners are 
Enkhchimeg Nergui
, Partnership Specialist, Mongolian National Confederation of Credit Unions, and 
Violet Ndungu
, CEO, Muki Sacco (Kenya).
Each will receive a grant of US $10,000 to implement projects aimed at advancing social and community impact efforts, and to uplift their members and communities. Project implementation will start in September and run through July 2024.
“Four 2022 GWLN Scholarship winners submitted Empowerment Grant proposals and were selected to present very distinct credit union projects on improving access to financial service products, savings and leadership opportunities for women in their communities,” explained GWLN Director Eleni Giakoumopoulos. “The four finalists made their presentations on July 23 during the GWLN Forum at the 2023 World Credit Union Conference in Vancouver, Canada. Forum attendees were asked to evaluate the presentations and proposals on their financial inclusivity, sustainability, creativity, planning and connection to GWLN, and ultimately vote to select two winners. This is a tremendous opportunity for these women to continue their efforts making impactful change in their communities, all through the support of GWLN.”
Enkhchimeg Nergui 
gave a presentation on her proposal to create a local business ecosystem in rural Mongolia that allows credit union members that are part of yak and sheep herder communities to diversify their income and promote eco-friendly and sustainable cashmere production.
Violet Ndungu 
presented the ways her SACCO would use the grant dollars to promote the commercialization of dairy farmers through strengthening and capacity building, increased dairy production, promoting new feed production technologies, and improving access to savings and loans for women and youth on dairy farms.
The four scholars were originally supposed to give presentations on their proposals during the 2022 World Credit Union Conference in Glasgow, Scotland, but were unable to attend due to visa issues.  
Each year, GWLN offers 
scholarships
 to encourage women leaders to attend the annual 
World Credit Union Conference
.
Empowerment grants were first offered in 2014, and past projects included the creation of business development centers in financial cooperatives to help female entrepreneurs, the development of a series of financial fitness workshops for young females as they get ready for college, and the design and implementation of a communication strategy to reach financially-excluded youth and women.
To learn how you can support the GWLN empowerment grants, contact GWLN at 
cuwomen@woccu.org
. Visit 
cuwomen@woccu.org
 for updates.
Empowerment Grant and scholarship funding is made possible through annual memberships and corporate donations, including generous support from 
Co-op Solutions
, 
OneAZ Credit Union
, 
Origence
, 
PSCU
 and 
TruStage
.
World Council of Credit Unions is the global trade association and development platform for credit unions. World Council promotes the sustainable development of credit unions and other financial cooperatives around the world to empower people through access to high quality and affordable financial services. World Council advocates on behalf of the global credit union system before international organizations and works with national governments to improve legislation and regulation. Its technical assistance programs introduce new tools and technologies to strengthen credit unions' financial performance and increase their outreach.
World Council has implemented 300+ technical assistance programs in 90 countries. Worldwide, 87,914 credit unions in 118 countries serve 393 million people. Learn more about World Council's impact around the world at 
www.woccu.org
.
Contact: 
Rachel Miller
E-mail: 
rmiller@woccu.org
Phone: 
608-395-2036
 
 
A registered charity organization with
P.O. Box 2982 • Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA • 
Foundation@woccu.org
 • DoGlobalGood.org
Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can update your preferences or 
unsubscribe from this list
.

WEBINAR: 
'Exploring African Culture'
Your Presenter:
Geremie Sawadago, 
HR Manager, World Bank Group
 
 
 
 
September 13, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
This webinar will explore
 the rich diversity in African cultures and discuss the case for African cultural unity around six shared cultural values, including: 
(1) communication style; (2) individualism/collectivism; (3) power distance; (4) uncertainty avoidance; (5) polychromic use of time; and (6) long term/short term orientation. 
 Participants will further their knowledge, appreciation and understanding of African cultures and learn tips to effectively communicate and interact with Africans in both a professional and personal context. 
 
Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing
 
Use Members Only Webinar Code: MBR_WBNR09
NOTE: The link below should now take you to the registration page for this event in September! Apologies for any confusion.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenter
Geremie Sawadago
Geremie Sawadogo is HR Manager at The World Bank Group in Washington DC.
  
Prior to joining the Bank, Geremie was the Country Director for the US Peace Corps in Benin, and he has also taught education and intercultural communication and directed international education programs at universities and community colleges across the US.
  
Geremie is a published 
author in the areas of intercultural competencies and international education, and he wrote the African cultural assessment tool (AfricanXculture.com) which allows individuals to assess themselves against an African cultural values benchmark.

Geremie Sawadago

Geremie is a published 
author in the areas of intercultural competencies and international education, and he wrote the African cultural assessment tool (AfricanXculture.com) which allows individuals to assess themselves against an African cultural values benchmark.

subject: Calendly Product Update – July 2023
body:
Upcoming webinar series, reducing no-shows, Calendly on the road, and more. 
͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ 
Hi Grace,
This is Jeff from Calendly with some tips and product updates for marketers, salespeople, and customer success professionals.
How Calendly Uses Calendly Webinar Series
Ever wonder how the Calendly team uses Calendly? We’re doing a lot more than sharing scheduling links. 
Join our webinar series, 
How Calendly Uses Calendly
, for a behind-the-scenes look at how leaders across our very own sales, marketing, customer success and recruiting teams use Calendly to do their best work and create 
real
 business results. Sign up to attend (and if you can’t, we’ll automatically email you the recording):
How Calendly Uses Calendly to Close More Deals
For Sales Teams
Tuesday, August 8 @ 10 am PT / 1pm ET
Register now →
How Calendly Uses Calendly to Retain More Customers
For Customer Success Teams
Tuesday, August 15 @ 10 am PT / 1 pm ET
Register now →
And, if you missed our 
CEO Tope’s session
 or 
mine with CMO Jessica
, you can watch the recordings some time by signing up. 
Sign Up for the Webinars
Tip of the Day: Reduce No-Shows
Are people getting flakier these days, not attending events they said they would? One study by OnePoll revealed the “average person is a no-show to almost half of the events they are invited to.”
One Calendly feature has reduced no-shows to my meetings 100%: 
Email Invitees to Reconfirm workflow
. I can’t recommend the feature enough – particularly for salespeople booking calls with prospects.
Available on the Professional Plan
, I trigger this reconfirmation email to go out one hour before a meeting. The recipient has to “reconfirm” the meeting with me. I then receive an email, advising they reconfirmed.
Since implementing this workflow, zero people have canceled meetings at the last minute! 
Give it a try, and let me know if you see similar success.
Use Workflows
Traveling More?
Don’t know about you, but I’m on the road a lot more in 2023. I can’t always lug around my laptop, so 
Calendly’s mobile app
 does the trick.
You can access your links, scan/reschedule upcoming events, or text a one-off meeting link—all from the palm of your hand. A lot of friends in Sales use the mobile app when they’re in the car between meetings. (Well, hopefully, they’re not using it while driving…) 
Get the iOS app
Get the Android app
Group Admins Can Help Other Admins
Your Calendly account admin has a lot on their plate. If that’s you, we have a new 
Professional subscription plan
 (and above) feature allowing you to 
shift some invite responsibility to group admins
.
After all, who better to invite users to a group than the people who oversee that group! Now group admins can own adding new hires to Calendly, enabling them to start scheduling meetings, fast.
A group admin can also be an admin for multiple groups 
without
 being a member. This allows for an org member to maintain group standardization at a large scale, while leaving day-to-day maintenance to a team lead.
Learn More
More Resources
Webinar: Build a Better Journey for Retention
Why sales, marketing, and customer success teams should embrace scheduling automation
Buyer’s Guide: Choosing a scheduling automation platform
Calendly for Enterprise overview
Thanks for reading, 
Jeff Hardison
Head of Product Marketing @ Calendly
 
 
 
 
Sent from Calendly
115 E. Main Street, Suite A1B,
Buford, GA 30518

subject: Exciting announcement from GlobalWA and Pangea Giving
body:
Press Release
 
Pangea Giving Joins Forces with Global Washington
 
(Seattle, WA - July 31, 2023) 
Global Washington
 (GlobalWA), a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization whose mission is to support the global development community in Washington State, announced today that 
Pangea Giving
, a Seattle-based giving circle operating since 2003, will become a program of GlobalWA starting August 1, 2023. The merger of the two organizations will create an unparalleled platform for global philanthropy and strategies to improve lives in low- and middle-income countries. 
 
As a program of GlobalWA, Pangea will be able to increase its member engagement, capacity, educational activities, partner relations, and programs in Seattle. For GlobalWA, having Pangea as part of its growing number of programs increases the ability for GlobalWA member organizations to co-create and partner with organizations based outside the U.S. for increased impact, and will create additional avenues of involvement for philanthropists. All with the ultimate vision to create a more equitable, healthy, and prosperous world.
 
 
“This is an exciting moment for both organizations,” said Kristen Dailey, Executive Director of Global Washington. “We will have enhanced services, educational events, and opportunities for co-creation that will include more diverse perspectives and support localization for better outcomes.  Merging with Pangea also builds on our work with our Women of the World program that supports female philanthropists who care about global issues.”
 
GlobalWA board member Jane Meseck is also looking forward to new opportunities, “GlobalWA members will now have more ways to collaborate with Pangea grantees and learn from in-country examples for global philanthropy. It also aligns beautifully with our new 
strategic plan,
 expanding our learning network to an impact network.”
 
“It’s a win-win agreement,” said Janet Pearson, Board President of Pangea. “When we formed Pangea in 2003 with the vision to promote more direct and positive international engagement, we could not have imagined a better outcome now 20 years later. By joining forces with GlobalWA we will be able to fulfill our mission even better and reach more individuals who want to join Pangea. And, this is really exciting and necessary, especially with the many challenges grassroots organizations and communities in the Global South face today.” Pearson then adds, “It satisfies our need for expanding grant development, partner relations, and Pangea member support.”
 
 
Pangea’s branding and name will be maintained as a program of GlobalWA.  A Pangea Advisory Council will be formed within GlobalWA to continue the vetting, recommendation, and evaluation of grants. The GlobalWA board will have ultimate fiduciary responsibility and final approval of grants, and one Pangea member would become a GlobalWA board member.
 
For any questions about this announcement, please email Joel Meyers, Director of Communications at 
comms@globalwa.org
. More information about the 
Pangea Giving Program
.
 
 
ABOUT GLOBAL WASHINGTON 
Global Washington supports non-profit organizations, businesses, foundations, and academic institutions in Washington state working to improve lives in low and middle income countries. We connect, promote, and strengthen our members, increasing their impact and advancing a vibrant, innovative, multi-stakeholder network. Our work is driven by the desire to create a more equitable, healthy, and prosperous world.
 
ABOUT PANGEA GIVING
Pangea Giving is a giving circle that gives their members and supporters direct, thoughtful, and effective ways to help grassroots organizations in the Global South to improve the quality of life in their communities. Their work includes leveraging resources, increasing visibility, sharing best practices, and advocating around education, global engagement, and foreign policy.
Our Contact Information
Global Washington
10115 Greenwood Ave N. #142
Seattle, WA 98133
info@globalwa.org
http://globalwa.org

subject: Coming Soon: Saturday Seminar from SIETAR USA!
body:
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!' - 9-Sept-2023 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
SATURDAY SEMINAR: 
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: 
One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!'
 
Your Seminar Leader:
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
 
 
 
 
September 9, 2023 @ 12:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
Have 
YOU
 registered yet? 
Don't miss this Saturday Seminar!  
Jay Cafferata
 will focus on how we unknowingly and unfortunately perpetuate racist ideology, colonialism, oppression, and discrimination in the words we use.  We'll be discussing the breakdown in communication between intercultural and inclusion dialogues. When we think about intercultural, we think international, global or worldwide – but when we think about inclusion, we think local, internal and the workplace. Why are we having these different conversations to the same discourse? What is the breakdown between these two seemingly different sets of vocabulary?
This interactive 4-hour session will include videos, polling, and breakout sessions. Participants are encouraged to join using a device that has a camera and a microphone as well as a secondary device like a phone or computer that allows for multiple windows to be open at the same time for the polling.
Participants will discuss and reflect on:
The words we use to describe others
Historical perspectives on these two lexicons
Global vs Local
The direction of impact: who is studying who?
At the conclusion of the presentation, participants will have:
A greater recognition of how inclusion and intercultural fit together.
The basic awareness of how we present ourselves in an environment or culture that is not necessarily our own.
Strategies to be more aware of where we are as professionals.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Registration Fees
$20 for Students
$45 for current SIETAR USA members in good standing
$65 for non-members
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Student-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Non-Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Your Seminar Leader
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
Mr. Cafferata is a well-known speaker and advocate for issues involving Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging. He considers himself a Social Justice Warrior and has spent decades as an advocate for the Sexual and Gender Minority Community. He has over 20 years of experience working with families of children with special needs. He has a master’s degree in communication studies from University of Nevada, Reno. and an associate degree in Deaf Studies from Western Nevada College. Mr. Cafferata is also a Certified Diversity Executive. He can be reached at 
jay@asltraining.com
.

subject: Credit Union Women Make Pitch for $10,000 Empowerment Grants
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
2023-07-23
Credit Union Women Make Pitch for $10,000 Empowerment Grants
2023 Athena Award also presented during GWLN events leading up to the World Credit Union Conference
 
Enkhchimeg Nergui (speaking), with Polly Gathoni Waweru and Violet Ndungu
 
Women Leading panel discussion
 
Sandra McDowell
 
More than 350 people attended the GWLN Forum
 
Eleni Giakoumopoulus presents Ida Rosette Ocampo with the 2023 Athena Award
VANCOUVER, British Columbia—Four 
Global Women’s Leadership Network
 (GWLN) scholars gave presentations aimed at securing $10,000 grants that would allow them to implement credit union projects empowering women during Sunday’s GWLN Forum at the 
2023 World Credit Union Conference
.
The four scholars originally submitted Empowerment Grant proposals as part of the 2022 GWLN Scholarship nomination process but were unable to attend the 2022 World Credit Union Conference in Glasgow, Scotland, due to visa issues related to COVID-19.
The 2022 GWLN Scholarship recipients who made their pitches were:
Dorothy Mambulasa
, Malawi Union of Savings and Credit Co-operatives, Ltd., on increasing access to both finances and solar energy products at Fincoop SACCO.
Enkhchimeg Nergui,
 Partnership Specialist, Mongolian National Confederation of Credit Unions, on creating a local business ecosystem that allows credit union members that are part of yak and sheep herder communities to diversify their income and promote eco-friendly and sustainable cashmere production.
Violet Ndungu
, CEO, Muki Sacco (Kenya), on promoting the commercialization of dairy farmers through strengthening and capacity building, increased dairy production, promoting new feed production technologies, and improving access to savings and loans for women and youth on dairy farms.
Polly Gathoni
 
Waweru
, Unisa Sacco Society Limited (Kenya): on creating a training program to promote women credit union empowerment by growing female membership, competencies’ building and leadership opportunities.
Each scholar got 15 minutes to make their pitch, with three presenting in person and Mambulasa submitting a video presentation.
“Attendees were encouraged to vote based on the creativity of each proposal, and how it addressed financial inclusion, sustainability, planning and the connection to GWLN,” said Eleni Giakoumopoulos, Director of Global Women’s Leadership Network (GWLN).
The results will be announced after the 2023 World Credit Union Conference, with the top two vote getters each receiving $10,000 Empowerment Grants.
A conversation with change makers
GWLN Forum attendees were also treated to a panel discussion on “Women Leading: A Conversation with Change Makers”, moderated by World Council of Credit Unions (WOCCU) Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning (MEL) Program Manager Dalia Mehiar, and featuring WOCCU President and CEO Elissa McCarter LaBorde.
The conversation centered around the theme of how to make credit unions and other workplaces in the industry more accessible to women who want to be leaders.
McCarter LaBorde said increasing access starts with organizations examining their hiring practices.
“I’ve had to specifically work with recruiters or hiring managers and say, ‘if you don’t come with three candidates that represent a diverse pool, then you haven’t worked hard enough,’” said McCarter LaBorde. “So, I see those things as related. Women who will step up to be a candidate and put themselves forward takes a lot of courage, just as it takes courage to be a hiring manager to bring on someone who isn’t maybe the most qualified but is going to round out your workforce or C-Suite team (diversity).”
Other panelists included Elenita San Roque, CEO of the Association of Asian Confederation of Credit Unions, Scholastica Odhiambo, Board Director of Cooperative Bank of Kenya and Hazina SACCO, and Miriam De Dios Woodward, Global CEO of ViClarity.
“Shut the Duck Up”
Forum attendees were also encouraged to “Shut the Duck Up” during a keynote address by Sandra McDowell, CEO and Founder of 
eLeadership Academy
.
McDowell relayed the message that many professionals who mentor or coach others do not spend enough time listening, because they are too anxious to insert their own thoughts or advice. She handed out small rubber ducks to drive that point home.
“There’s what’s called the 80/20 rule which you’ve heard of, of course—it also applies to coaching. Who does the 80% apply to, the coachee or the coach? If you’re having a true coaching conversation, you should only be speaking about 20% of the time,” said McDowell. “And if you find yourself talking, you can ask yourself – why am I talking? And you can look at your duck and remind yourself to shut the duck up.”   
Athena Award goes to Ocampo
Ida Rosette Ocampo received the 2023 Athena Award during Saturday’s GWLN Reception at WCUC 2023.
Serving as Chief Officer for Administration at Barangka Credit Cooperative in The Philippines, Ocampo began her GWLN journey at the 2017 World Credit Union Conference.
She has since established the Barangka Credit Cooperative Sister Society and worked through the cooperative and the Sister Society to foster professional development and network building to advance leadership training, facilitate financial-stability centric webinars for their members, and to secure a gender balance in governance by targeting the diversity on boards and within executive leadership to better mirror Barangka Cooperative’s member base.
“I will continue my work to empower women in credit unions along with the mission of GWLN,” said Ocampo. “I am truly grateful for the opportunity to be part of this network and to work with so many talented and dedicated men and women leaders. I’m excited to see what the future holds for the global credit union movement, and I am confident that, together, we can make a difference.”
The Athena Award is inspired by the goddess of Greek mythology who stands for strength, courage, and wisdom and is presented to an individual or organization making an outstanding contribution to women's leadership in the international credit union movement.
2023 GWLN Scholarship recipients
 were also recognized during Saturday’s reception.
TruStage
 was the lead sponsor of this weekend’s GWLN events, along with co-sponsors: 
Co-op Solutions
, 
OneAZ Credit Union
, 
Origence
 and 
PSCU
.
Still to come
The 
2023 World Credit Union Conference
 officially begins Sunday afternoon with the opening ceremony, followed by a welcome reception in the Solution Center.
Follow conference activities and see daily event photos on 
Facebook
, 
Twitter
, 
LinkedIn
 and 
Instagram
 with #WCUC2023.
Presented in collaboration with the 
Canadian Credit Union Association (CCUA)
, the 2023 World Credit Union Conference runs through Wednesday, July 26.
World Council of Credit Unions is the global trade association and development platform for credit unions. World Council promotes the sustainable development of credit unions and other financial cooperatives around the world to empower people through access to high quality and affordable financial services. World Council advocates on behalf of the global credit union system before international organizations and works with national governments to improve legislation and regulation. Its technical assistance programs introduce new tools and technologies to strengthen credit unions' financial performance and increase their outreach.
World Council has implemented 300+ technical assistance programs in 90 countries. Worldwide, 87,914 credit unions in 118 countries serve 393 million people. Learn more about World Council's impact around the world at 
www.woccu.org
.
Contact: 
Greg Neumann
E-mail: 
gneumann@woccu.org
Phone: 
+1 608-395-2048
World Council of Credit Unions
P.O. Box 2982, Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA
Phone: +1-608-395-2000 | Fax: +1-608-395-2001 | 
mail@woccu.org
 | 
www.woccu.org

subject: July: Supporting Refugees - Reduced Inequalities (SDG 10)
body:
July: Supporting Refugees - Reduced Inequalities (SDG 10)  
Table of Contents
Issue Brief
Organization Profile
Goalmaker Spotlight
July Links
New Members
Events
 
Careers
Dear Grace,
 
Over the past two years, there has been a dramatic increase in the number of people forcibly displaced around the world. 19 million people left their homes in 2022 due to conflict, violence, climate change, and other factors making their living situation unbearable. This brought the total number of refugees and displaced people to 108.4 million – a staggering number of people – and solutions for support and resettlement are becoming increasingly challenging.
 
However, I am hopeful that refugees are finding safe places and services due in part to Global Washington members. This includes emergency responses in places such as Ukraine and long-standing crises in regions such as Yemen and Myanmar, and ongoing programs for settlement and self-reliance. The expertise and resources that our GlobalWA members are bringing to bear is admirable and is certainly making a difference. Read more about these efforts below.
 
Several of the programs described below are done in partnership with one or more GlobalWA members. Collaboration and building trusting relationships are what GlobalWA is all about. Our network is growing stronger each year as we respond to member needs, make valued connections, and promote innovative approaches to global development. We are extremely excited about our new 
strategic plan
 and centering the principles of co-creation throughout our work. We will have new member offerings and new member rates as of August 1st, 2023 to better reflect the growth and quality we aim to provide. You can read more about our new 
member benefits here
. If your organization is interested in becoming a new GlobalWA member, please contact us at 
info@globalwa.org
. 
 
Sincerely,
Kristen Dailey
Executive Director
 
ISSUE BRIEF
From Survival to Self-Reliance - GlobalWA Members Untangle the Complexities of the Refugee Crisis
 
Reducing inequalities for all, the central pillar of Sustainable Development Goal 10, is a sentiment exemplified in no small part by efforts to address the rampant and growing refugee crisis. The lack of access to resources, whether they be vital for survival or instrumental in economic success, is a persistent issue present in refugee communities the world over. The number of people displaced around the world due to war, human rights abuses, and persecution reached up to 108.4 million as of 2022, according to the 
UNHCR’s Global Trends Report
. Increasingly strict refugee admission laws have exacerbated the disaster, highlighting a stark pushback against the acceptance of displaced persons. 
Continue ››
 
ORGANIZATION PROFILE
Organization Profile: Better Than a Movie: Operation Snow Leopard (Afghanistan)
 
Imagine that your country is in turmoil and you may need to flee your home. You’ll have to leave parts of your family, your livelihood, your community, and your belongings. Where can you go? When is the right time to leave? How will you get there? Maybe the fighting isn’t too close yet, maybe your city won’t fall. And then maybe it’s too late to get to safety. Or maybe your partner or child is too sick. Who can help? For many people around the world, this is a very real scene from their lives. 
Continue ››
 
GOALMAKER SPOTLIGHT
Elfatih Abdelnabi, Immigration Program Manager, International Rescue Committee
 
It started with his own family. Now, Elfatih Abdelnabi helps refugees all over the world reunite with theirs.
 
Elfatih Abdelnabi never expected he would end up in Seattle. In fact, at first, he didn’t even know where Seattle was. 
Continue ››

Subject:
 new client/project - June 20 availability
 
 
Hello Almendra,
 
It was so lovely to facilitate with you the other month! I was hoping to have an opportunity to work together again, and a new client need has come up. I am reaching out to see if you are both available and interested in supporting a few deliveries of our Understanding Microaggressions training. The courses will be delivered in English, but our client (the Inter-American Development Bank) is eager for a facilitator that can receive and answer questions in Spanish. I also think it will make the training even more effective.
 
Are you interested? And if you are, might you be available for an initial training on June 20 from 3-4:30 PM EST? 
 
I’d love to set up a quick time to chat through the project if you’re interested and able (even if you can’t make that specific time work) – let me know what you think!
 
Thanks,
Grace
 
------------------------------------------------------
Grace Vottero

subject: Ready for a Saturday Seminar from SIETAR USA?
body:
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!' - Sept 9, 2023 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
SATURDAY SEMINAR: 
'Intercultural vs. Inclusion: 
One Looks Out, the Other Looks In!'
 
Your Seminar Leader:
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
 
 
 
 
September 9, 2023 @ 12:00 PM - 4:00 PM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
In this first Saturday Seminar for 2023, self-professed Social Justice 
Warrior
 
Jay Cafferata
 will focus on how we unknowingly and unfortunately perpetuate racist ideology, colonialism, oppression, and discrimination in the words we use.  We'll be discussing the breakdown in communication between intercultural and inclusion dialogues. When we think about intercultural, we think international, global or worldwide – but when we think about inclusion, we think local, internal and the workplace. Why are we having these different conversations to the same discourse? What is the breakdown between these two seemingly different sets of vocabulary?
This interactive 4-hour session will include videos, polling, and breakout sessions. Participants are encouraged to join using a device that has a camera and a microphone as well as a secondary device like a phone or computer that allows for multiple windows to be open at the same time for the polling.
Participants will discuss and reflect on:
The words we use to describe others
Historical perspectives on these two lexicons
Global vs Local
The direction of impact: who is studying who?
At the conclusion of the presentation, participants will have:
A greater recognition of how inclusion and intercultural fit together.
The basic awareness of how we present ourselves in an environment or culture that is not necessarily our own.
Strategies to be more aware of where we are as professionals.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Registration Fees
$20 for Students
$45 for current SIETAR USA members in good standing
$65 for non-members
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Student-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Non-Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Your Seminar Leader
Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE
Mr. Cafferata is a well-known speaker and advocate for issues involving Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging. He considers himself a Social Justice Warrior and has spent decades as an advocate for the Sexual and Gender Minority Community. He has over 20 years of experience working with families of children with special needs. He has a master’s degree in communication studies from University of Nevada, Reno. He holds an associate degree in Deaf Studies from Western Nevada College. Mr. Cafferata is also a Certified Diversity Executive. He can be reached at 
jay@asltraining.com
.

Jay Cafferata, MS, CDE

For right now it turns out that we will not need support on June 20, but we expect a good amount of these trainings with this client, so I’d still love to find time, bring you up to speed on the client, and get in a good place for when their requests start coming in. This coming week and a half is exceptionally busy for us as we head to Chicago for our retreat. Could you meet on June 1
st
 or 2
nd

Talk to you soon!
 
Best,
Grace

>

 Vince Bongiovanni <
v.bongiovanni@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 new client/project - June 20 availability
 
 
Hello Almendra,
 
It was so lovely to facilitate with you the other month! I was hoping to have an opportunity to work together again, and a new client need has come up. I am reaching out to see if you are both available and interested in supporting a few deliveries of our Understanding Microaggressions training. The courses will be delivered in English, but our client (the Inter-American Development Bank) is eager for a facilitator that can receive and answer questions in Spanish. I also think it will make the training even more effective.
 
Are you interested? And if you are, might you be available for an initial training on June 20 from 3-4:30 PM EST? 
 
I’d love to set up a quick time to chat through the project if you’re interested and able (even if you can’t make that specific time work) – let me know what you think!
 
Thanks,
Grace
 
------------------------------------------------------

subject: Vancouver’s Celebration of Light Cruise @ WCUC!
body:
Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions (WFCU) is hosting a variety of events at the 
2023 World Credit Union Conference in Vancouver, Canada! 
This Weeks Highlighted Event: 
Celebration of Light Cruise
Wednesday, July 26th
7:30 p.m. to 11:30 p.m. 
(boarding starts at 6:30 p.m.)
$200 per person
There is nothing quite like fireworks, and you haven’t really seen fireworks until you’ve experienced Vancouver’s Celebration of Light! This signature summer event brings together over 1.3 million regional and international visitors every summer to the shores of English Bay.  Three countries compete each year to wow Vancouver crowds, choreographing their spectacular displays to music as they’re launched off a floating barge in the bay. Close out your WCUC experience with a once-in-a-lifetime experience to witness Vancouver's annual Celebration of Light Festival on a yacht cruise in English Bay. By attending, you will help advance WFCU's mission of growing credit unions worldwide in partnership with WOCCU. 
**
The cruise facilitates a cocktail reception and the celebration viewing.
WFCU
Global DE Social
Celebration of Light Cruise
Give Back Opportunity
GWLN
GWLN Reception
GWLN Forum
WYCUP
WYCUP Emerging Leaders' Summit
All proceeds of these WFCU events @ WCUC support our 
2023 Bridge the Gap Campaign
, helping credit unions and their members overcome global challenges.
 
 
A registered charity organization with
P.O. Box 2982 • Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA • 
Foundation@woccu.org
 • DoGlobalGood.org

subject: Managing Toxic Employees: Strategies For Leaders To Effectively Deal With Employee Attitude Issues
body:
Dear colleagues
Amidst the stress and uncertainty of today's world, hostile and resistant team members can become even more challenging. As a leader, it becomes imperative to understand and respond appropriately to their behaviors to reduce workplace drama and cultivate a positive, productive environment. The webinar will explore the challenges of managing difficult employees, mastering the art of effectively controlling our emotions, and creating an environment that fosters positivity and growth.
 
Managing Toxic Employees: Strategies For Leaders To Effectively Deal With Employee Attitude Issues
Speaker
 -     Beverly Beuermann-King 
Duration:
 60 minutes 
              Date: 
July 14, 2023, | 
Time: 
01: 00 PM EST
 
Pick Your Seat Now
 and get $31 off using code 
"YTB31".
 
 
Session Highlights:
The speaker will develop an understanding of those exhibiting typical complex attitudes to meet their needs and move the interactions forward effectively.
Utilize various verbal and non-verbal communication techniques and situational strategies that you can use to de-escalate and effectively handle difficult people.
Uncover the secret to moving difficult conversations forward
Utilize a Model for Conversations about Difficult Attitudes
Learn how to act, not react, in solving situations to lead more confidently, feel less stress, and succeed more in working and interacting with your team.
Why should you Attend:-
 
 Attendees will be able to recognize the hurdles of overseeing challenging employees. Furthermore, they will develop the skills to respond positively to difficult employees, treating them fairly and impartially.
 
Who Should Attend:-
Anyone with Managerial or Leadership Responsibility
In case of any issue, contact us at
 +1-844-899-4647 Email: cs@compliancewebworld.com

subject: RE: LCW Consultant Introduction
body:

subject: Don't Forget: July 12 Webinar from SIETAR USA!
body:
"Belonging: A Journey for Each of Us" w/ Megan Norton ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
WEBINAR: 
"Belonging: A Journey for Each of Us"
Your Presenter:
Megan Norton, 
Author, TCK Consultant & Intercultural Trainer
 
 
 
 
July 12, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
Having a sense of belonging - or multiple belongings - is a journey for every individual to reflect on and celebrate. Increasingly we participate in conversations about “belonging” in multiple sectors and with several lenses. What does it mean to have a ‘sense of belonging’ when your entire life has been shaped by global mobility and different cultures? Third Culture Kids (TCKs) deal with issues of belonging because they have spent a significant part of their upbringing crossing cultures. Their experiences can make it challenging to find, form, and sustain a sense of belonging. In this webinar, Megan leads the discussion about what it means to belong in multiple communities: personal, professional, familial, cultural, and spiritual. Megan invites participants to ponder how to belong, where to belong, and why to belong.
 
Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing
 
Use Members Only Webinar Code: MBR_WBNR
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenter
Megan Norton
Megan Norton is an author, Third Culture Kid (TCK) consultant, intercultural trainer, podcast host of 
A Culture Story
, and writer at 
adultthirdculturekid.com
. Growing up as a U.S. diplomat dependent, she lived in 6 countries (US., South Africa, South Korea, Germany, Japan, Israel), also as an adult in 4 more countries (Austria, Greece, Hungary, Poland) in addition to 5 U.S. States. She leads both in-person and virtual TCK Transitions Seminars, university retreats and Intercultural Dialogue groups for a variety of international entities. An active member of Families in Global Transition, she served on the Board of Directors from 2018 – 2022 and has been the co-chair of the NAFSA Global Nomad/TCK Member Interest Group for the past 6 years. Her book, 
Belonging Beyond Borders: How Adult Third Culture Kids Can Cultivate a Sense of Belonging
, equips and empowers globally mobile youth to recognize their cultural competencies and apply them in various contexts. 
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenter
Megan Norton
Megan Norton is an author, Third Culture Kid (TCK) consultant, intercultural trainer, podcast host of 
A Culture Story
, and writer at 
adultthirdculturekid.com
. Growing up as a U.S. diplomat dependent, she lived in 6 countries (US., South Africa, South Korea, Germany, Japan, Israel), also as an adult in 4 more countries (Austria, Greece, Hungary, Poland) in addition to 5 U.S. States. She leads both in-person and virtual TCK Transitions Seminars, university retreats and Intercultural Dialogue groups for a variety of international entities. An active member of Families in Global Transition, she served on the Board of Directors from 2018 – 2022 and has been the co-chair of the NAFSA Global Nomad/TCK Member Interest Group for the past 6 years. Her book, 
Belonging Beyond Borders: How Adult Third Culture Kids Can Cultivate a Sense of Belonging
, equips and empowers globally mobile youth to recognize their cultural competencies and apply them in various contexts.

subject: Calendly Product Update – June 2023
body:
Team scheduling tips, Routing feature overview, and more.
͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ ͏ 
Hi Grace,
This is Jeff from Calendly wondering how my fellow marketing, sales, and customer success folks are doing! Here’s the latest updates from our team to yours.
Features Our Team Can't
Live Without
In a video
, we at Calendly got together to share three of our favorite team scheduling tips that our own sales, marketing, and customer success teams rely on every day. It’s “Calendly on Calendly” if you will.
You can now catch the 
on-demand webinar
 that includes the tips and live demos.
The short transcript of our tips: 
Collective scheduling
 for bringing a coworker like a sales engineer, your boss, or a marketing colleague to a customer meeting (
Professional plan and above
)
Round Robin
 for sharing meeting opportunities with coworkers — like a pool of salespeople or customer success managers — depending on their availability (
Teams plan and above
)
Managed Events
 for ensuring your teammates are all using the same templates — to standardize the customer experience, reduce typos, and more (
Teams plan and above
)
Watch the Live Tutorial
Watch How Routing Works
We’ve written a bit about our new feature Routing, which allows you to qualify, route and schedule meetings with prospects – right from your site. But sometimes you need videos to bring the story to life.
Our coworker Meryl made this 
super-helpful video about Routing
 that I encourage you to watch.
Also, our 
customer Bryce from Smith.ai
 sat down with us at the Forrester conference to talk about their experience implementing Routing… in 30 minutes! This is a very raw, quickly conceived iPhone video, but I’m sure you’ve been there!
Last, our partners 
HubSpot and ZoomInfo joined us in a webinar
 to share how you can instantly schedule your best leads with Calendly Routing to both close deals faster and provide a better experience for your customers.
As you’ve heard from us, these partners make our new 
Routing
 solution better. Signup form providers like HubSpot allow you to integrate qualification questions with your existing “talk-to-sales” experience on your website. And business-data companies like ZoomInfo help “enrich” the customer-shared contact data with “firmagraphic” details such as company size, industry, and more. 
Learn more here
.
Watch the Customer Video
More Resources
Why sales, marketing, and customer success teams should embrace scheduling automation
Buyer’s Guide: Choosing a scheduling automation platform
Calendly for Enterprise overview
Thanks for reading, 
Jeff Hardison
Head of Product Marketing @ Calendly
 
 
 
 
Sent from Calendly
115 E. Main Street, Suite A1B,
Buford, GA 30518

An active member of Families in Global Transition, she served on the Board of Directors from 2018 – 2022 and has been the co-chair of the NAFSA Global Nomad/TCK Member Interest Group for the past 6 years. Her book, 
Belonging Beyond Borders: How Adult Third Culture Kids Can Cultivate a Sense of Belonging
, equips and empowers globally mobile youth to recognize their cultural competencies and apply them in various contexts.

The Global Credit Union Podcast - Episode 26: A Preview of the 2023 World Credit Union Conference
Brian Harris, President and CEO of

in British Columbia, Canada—home to next month’s

subject: Webinar: The Social Value Measurement Opportunity: Building on Credit Union Strengths To Enhance Impact
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
Webinar: The Social Value Measurement Opportunity: Building on Credit Union Strengths To Enhance Impact 
Time: Wednesday, June 28 at 10:00 am CT 
The best banking deals create value for a range of other stakeholders through improvement in physical and mental health and enhancing wellbeing. This is the type of banking offered by credit unions, and represents a key opportunity for differentiation in financial services markets. The challenge is that measuring the social value of our work through the risk focused measurement approaches of standard ESG frameworks often understates our performance (or misses non- financial value creation entirely). These limitations create an environment where an important opportunity for Credit Unions to leverage purpose and mission as a strategic differentiator is underutilized, but there is work underway to solve for this.
During this session Keith Taylor will share more about the DUCA Impact Lab’s work with Simetrica Jacobs (UK) and Social Value Canada to address these challenges. 
By attending this session you will:
Expand understanding of the social value outcomes of credit union products.
Learn how the impact credit union's have on society can be valued.
Gain insight into practical opportunities to enhance the effectiveness of ESG programs.
This session is presented by: 
Keith Taylor
Executive Director, DUCA Impact Lab
DUCA Credit Union
Canada
World Council of Credit Unions
P.O. Box 2982, Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA

body:
"Belonging: A Journey for Each of Us" w/ Megan Norton ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
WEBINAR: 
"Belonging: A Journey for Each of Us"
Your Presenter:
Megan Norton, 
Author, TCK Consultant & Intercultural Trainer
 
 
 
 
July 12, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
Having a sense of belonging - or multiple belongings - is a journey for every individual to reflect on and celebrate. Increasingly we participate in conversations about “belonging” in multiple sectors and with several lenses. What does it mean to have a ‘sense of belonging’ when your entire life has been shaped by global mobility and different cultures? Third Culture Kids (TCKs) deal with issues of belonging because they have spent a significant part of their upbringing crossing cultures. Their experiences can make it challenging to find, form, and sustain a sense of belonging. In this webinar, Megan leads the discussion about what it means to belong in multiple communities: personal, professional, familial, cultural, and spiritual. Megan invites participants to ponder how to belong, where to belong, and why to belong.
 
Registration = FREE for current SIETAR USA members in good standing
 
Use Members Only Webinar Code: MBR_WBNR
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member-Register 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
About Your Presenter
Megan Norton
Megan Norton is an author, Third Culture Kid (TCK) consultant, intercultural trainer, podcast host of 
A Culture Story
, and writer at 
adultthirdculturekid.com
. Growing up as a U.S. diplomat dependent, she lived in 6 countries (US., South Africa, South Korea, Germany, Japan, Israel), also as an adult in 4 more countries (Austria, Greece, Hungary, Poland) in addition to 5 U.S. States. She leads both in-person and virtual TCK Transitions Seminars, university retreats and Intercultural Dialogue groups for a variety of international entities. An active member of Families in Global Transition, she served on the Board of Directors from 2018 – 2022 and has been the co-chair of the NAFSA Global Nomad/TCK Member Interest Group for the past 6 years. Her book,

, equips and empowers globally mobile youth to recognize their cultural competencies and apply them in various contexts.

subject: Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions Launches Resilience Initiative in Ukraine
body:
Read this in your browser.
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
2023-06-21
Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions Launches Resilience Initiative in Ukraine
$500,000 allocated for credit union loans targeting vulnerable populations and sustainable development
 
Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions
 (WFCU) this week tapped its 
Ukrainian Credit Union Displacement Fund
 for $500,000 to launch a new credit union lending program aimed at assisting vulnerable populations and boosting sustainable development in Ukraine.
Working in cooperation with the 
USAID/WOCCU Credit for Agriculture Producers (CAP) Project
, WFCU launched its Resilience Initiative after signing agreements with two United (Central) Credit Unions (UCUs) in Ukraine. The UCUs will pass the $500,000 on to individual credit unions, so they can provide loans aimed at stimulating rural and agricultural business recovery and growth and supporting vulnerable populations amid Russia’s ongoing war against Ukraine. Resilience Initiative lending will target:
Businesses owned by women, or by those who were either internally displaced or left the country due to the war and have now returned to Ukraine.
Sustainable finance for micro-, small- and medium-sized businesses located in rural areas.
The structure of this program is similar to that of the 
$1 million USAID/WFCU Liquidity Fund
 that was set up in 2021 and has proven to be an efficient means of boosting agricultural lending through credit unions in rural Ukrainian communities. As of April 30, 2023, credit unions had disbursed 954 agricultural loans totaling $2.3 million from the Liquidity Fund under WFCU and CAP Project supervision. 621 of those loans, totaling $1.46 million, have been issued since Russia launched its full-scale invasion in February 2022.
With credit unions well-positioned to address the significant financial challenges facing Ukrainians, including those internally displaced or returning from abroad and those who stayed in their communities devastated by war, it is critical to provide incentive programs and additional funds to credit unions to share risks and build long-lasting relationships, especially with new businesses and members.
Since the start of Russia’s invasion, WFCU has implemented seven relief programs totaling over $645,000 that have focused on providing immediate assistance to the Ukrainian credit unions and their members. For more information, please see the 
WFCU Relief Results report
.
To donate to the Ukrainian Credit Union Displacement Fund, 
click here
.
The Worldwide Foundation is the fundraising and engagement arm of the World Council. Join us on a global journey to transform a billion lives worldwide using credit unions. Visit 
www.doglobalgood.org
 to start your journey today.
World Council of Credit Unions is the global trade associati
on and development platform for credit unions. World Council promotes the sustainable development of credit unions and other financial cooperatives around the world to empower people through access to high quality and affordable financial services. World Council advocates on behalf of the global credit union system before international organizations and works with national governments to improve legislation and regulation. Its technical assistance programs introduce new tools and technologies to strengthen credit unions' financial performance and increase their outreach.
World Council has implemented 300+ technical assistance programs in 90 countries. Worldwide, 87,914 credit unions in 118 countries serve 393 million people. Learn more about World Council's impact around the world at 
www.woccu.org
.
Contact: 
Greg Neumann
E-mail: 
gneumann@woccu.org
Phone: 
+1 608-395-2048
 
 
A registered charity organization with
P.O. Box 2982 • Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA •

Additionally, would you help me with confirming the following pieces of information?

subject: A Preview of the 2023 World Credit Union Conference on Episode 26 of the Global Credit Union Podcast
body:
Read on web
 | 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent to: g.vottero@lcwmail.com
 
The Global Credit Union Podcast - Episode 26: A Preview of the 2023 World Credit Union Conference
Brian Harris, President and CEO of
 
Interior Savings Credit Union
 
in British Columbia, Canada—home to next month’s
 
2023 World Credit Union Conference
—joins us on 
Episode 26 of The Global Credit Union Podcast
 to talk about the vibrant region and, more specifically, the City of Vancouver and all it has to offer the more than 3,000 credit union professionals who will be converging on it from July 23-26.
Plus, with Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions and its Global Women’s Leadership Network (GWLN) and WYCUP programs 
hosting more events in conjunction with a World Credit Union Conference than ever before
, Mike Reuter, Executive Director of the Worldwide Foundation, joins GWLN Director Lena Giakoumopoulos and WYCUP Manager Ari Farrell to preview
 
those activities.
This episode has all you need to help you get ready for #wcuc2023!
                                       
                                    
You can find past episodes of The Global Credit Union Podcast by
 
clicking here
. To suggest a topic or guest for a future episode, contact Greg Neumann, World Council Director of Communications, at
 
gneumann@woccu.org
.
World Council of Credit Unions
P.O. Box 2982, Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA
Phone: +1-608-395-2000 | Fax: +1-608-395-2001 | 
mail@woccu.org
 | 
www.woccu.org

subject: Vancouver’s Celebration of Light Cruise!
body:
Worldwide Foundation for Credit Unions (WFCU) is hosting a variety of events at the 
2023 World Credit Union Conference in Vancouver, Canada! 
This Weeks Highlighted Event: 
Celebration of Light Cruise
Wednesday, July 26th
7:30 p.m. to 11:30 p.m. 
(boarding starts at 6:30 p.m.)
$200 per person
There is nothing quite like fireworks, and you haven’t really seen fireworks until you’ve experienced Vancouver’s Celebration of Light! This signature summer event brings together over 1.3 million regional and international visitors every summer to the shores of English Bay.  Three countries compete each year to wow Vancouver crowds, choreographing their spectacular displays to music as they’re launched off a floating barge in the bay. Close out your WCUC experience with a once-in-a-lifetime experience to witness Vancouver's annual Celebration of Light Festival on a yacht cruise in English Bay. By attending, you will help advance WFCU's mission of growing credit unions worldwide in partnership with WOCCU. 
**
The cruise facilitates a cocktail reception and the celebration viewing.
WFCU
Global DE Social
Celebration of Light Cruise
Give Back Opportunity
GWLN
GWLN Reception
GWLN Forum
WYCUP
WYCUP Emerging Leaders' Summit
All proceeds of these WFCU events @ WCUC support our 
2023 Bridge the Gap Campaign
, helping credit unions and their members overcome global challenges.
 
 
A registered charity organization with
P.O. Box 2982 • Madison, WI 53701-2982 USA • 
Foundation@woccu.org
 • DoGlobalGood.org
Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can update your preferences or 
unsubscribe from this list
.

subject: Creating The Life Satisfaction, You Desire: The Myth of Balance
body:
Creating The Life Satisfaction, You Desire: The Myth of Balance
Live Webinar | 
Beverly Beuermann-King
 
| Jun 30, 2023 , 01 : 00 PM EST | 60 Minutes
Get 
"$29"
 off. Eligibility Code: 
"SAVE29"
Register Now
Description:-
Many have noticed that their work-life boundaries have blurred, and they have not taken a real break since the start of the pandemic.
It is essential that we find the strategies to manage our energy, focus on happiness, and integrate all aspects of our life. But how do we do that when we are time-pressured, reactive, tired out, and running on empty? Failing to focus on taking a break and creating balance and life satisfaction can lead to burnout, mental health challenges, and a variety of physical health repercussions.
Examine your personal Wheel of Life and discover how you allocate your energy. By applying simplicity strategies to the S-O-S Principle, you will be able to discover a renewed sense of balance, engagement, and health.
Areas Covered:-
Key messages:
Balance does not mean equal
Balance is continually changing
Balance and life satisfaction are activities that you continually engage in as you make corrections throughout the day, week, and months ahead. Focus is on more of what you love and less of what you loathe
As we move through challenge and out of crisis mode and transition into the next phase of adjustments, focusing on balance and life satisfaction is a critical part of staying mentally fit
Simplicity: Small shifts can make major impacts on how engaged and satisfied you are with your life
You owe it to yourself to make sure you are maintaining a healthy work-life balance that allows you to thrive, both personally and professionally
Participants will:
Discover the results that a lack of balance has and the way that it is impacting their productivity, health, and enjoyment and that of their teams
Identify the many areas of priority and importance in life. Examine the Wheel of Life model to map strategies for how we allocate our energy
Focus on Simplicity. Small shifts can make major impacts on how engaged and satisfied you are with your life
Understand and identify the many energy drainers and utilize energy boosters to free up mental and physical energy
Gain clarity, a sense of direction, and motivation to live life with contentment, calmness, and connection
Why You Should Attend:-
Research shows that this is a normal response when a crisis occurs, but as the pandemic wears on, it is important to regain the focus on living a full and flourishing life despite the circumstances.
Balance can feel like an unrealistic dream. Balance is an activity that you must continually engage in as you make corrections and adjustments based on circumstances. Balance becomes the harmonious simplification and integration of all aspects of life, including coping with business disruption, working remotely, and other impacts of the pandemic.
Examine your personal Wheel of Life and discover how you allocate your energy. By applying simplicity strategies to the S-O-S Principle, you will be able to discover a renewed sense of balance, engagement, and health during this current challenge and as you move forward.
Or more than 6 attendee call us at 
+1-877-896-6748 
or mail us at 
cs@ineducator.com
You can choose to stop receiving updates from us 
Unsubscribe Here

7201 Wisconsin Ave Suite 440 Bethesda, MD 20814

subject: FW: Follow Up - LCW <> IDB Global Federal Credit Union
body:
From:
 Grace Vottero 
Sent:
 Wednesday, May 10, 2023 3:40 PM
To:
 Schwartz, Mark <MarkS@idbglobalfcu.org>; Sandoval, Andre <AndreS@idbglobalfcu.org>
Cc:
 Vince Bongiovanni <v.bongiovanni@lcwmail.com>; Melissa Neu <m.neu@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Follow Up - LCW <> IDB Global Federal Credit Union
 
Hi Mark,
 
It was wonderful to learn more about your Credit Union and your plans for engaging and providing learning and development for staff.
Your comment about the role profile for the training is excellent, thank you for asking! It is true that we do often recommend the Understanding Microaggressions for Managers & Leaders – at a minimum – because we know they play a fundamental role in interrupting microaggressions and creating cultures and teams where microinequities can be called out, explored, and mitigated. Especially for larger organizations that are often logistically constrained in delivering training to all audiences, we want to ensure that the leaders and managers of the organization receive this training either before, or alongside with, the other employees and individual contributors.
 
All that said, the Understanding Microaggressions training is perfect for an organization-wide delivery, as you are proposing with the two deliveries for your 51 team members. In my opinion, this training and the related conversations are truly enhanced when it is an organization-wide conversation.
 
Thank you so much for sharing your DEI plan, I’m looking forward to reading through and discussing further. In the interim, I am also sharing an updated version of the cost proposal, reflecting two deliveries of the training.
 
Let me know if you and Andres have time this Friday, or perhaps next Monday or Tuesday, to connect and talk through questions and next steps?
 
Talk to you soon!
 
Best,
 
------------------------------------------------------
Grace Vottero
(she/her/hers)
Consultant,
 LCW

g.vottero@lcwmail.com

Hi Grace,
 
I want to thank you for meeting with Andre and me this past week to learn more about our Credit Union, what we are looking to provide to our staff, and for the additional information provided.d
 
In reviewing the Overview Presentation, Understanding Microaggressions training is recommended for Leaders and Managers, whereas we had planned to provide this training for all 51 of our staff. We want to be all inclusive on the DEI learnings journey, however, I would appreciate your thoughts if you would suggest otherwise or have another recommendation.  If we do provide this training to everyone, we would want to offer 2 sessions, as we will need to remain open to serve our members.  If this would be an additional expense, we would also need to review a revised cost proposal.
 
I have included our DEI Plan as requested and welcome additional feedback. Looking forward to hearing from you and continuing our discussion.

Mark

The learning journeys that I mentioned in our chat can be found on pages 16-18, broken down based on audience (all employees, people managers, senior leaders).

subject: FW: MMC Follow-up: more info for you!
body:
This is the last proposal email that MMC received
 
From:
 Grace Vottero 
Sent:
 Friday, June 9, 2023 5:04 PM
To:
 Tina Anderson (MMC) <tina.anderson@hellommc.com>
Subject:
 RE: MMC Follow-up: more info for you!
 
Hi Tina,
 
We really are! I am attaching two documents – and updated and refined proposal overview with session details, and the draft Statement of Work. This includes the 30% discount being applied for anything 
signed before June 30 
– please let me know if you want me to also share a copy without the 30%.
 
It’s great to confirm the 12-month timing. I think that makes sense. I have included the initial timing by month in the project design, but it would be amazing to talk through and confirm exactly what you had in mind.
 
What you have described sounds great. I want to be sure that for the Leaders, we plan on completion of the IDI and their individual debriefs prior to Building a Culture of Inclusion, since our intention is for the first workshop to include the Group IDI debrief. If you think we should change this, we could talk about mixing it up a bit and doing a deliver of BCI without the IDI and before the test is even administered – but let’s talk that through?!
 
Regarding in-person/virtual – right now, I’ve only applied the on-site premium to the two deliveries of BCI that we’ll do in-person. This means that everything else – so for leaders BCI Part 1 and BCI Part 2/ How to Disrupt Bias When Evaluating Talent – and for all audiences – the other two deliveries of BCI and 4 virtual deliveries of Managing Unconscious Bias in the Workplace (as a note, I recommend this course be deliver virtually). 
 
Please do not hesitate to reach out with questions, edits, etc.
Talk to you soon, and I hope you have a lovely weekend!
 
Thanks,
Grace
 
 
From:
 Tina Anderson (MMC) <
tina.anderson@hellommc.com
> 
Sent:
 Friday, June 9, 2023 10:05 AM
To:
 Grace Vottero <
g.vottero@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 MMC Follow-up: more info for you!
 
Great chat, Grace, we are on a roll!
I've just learned from Jen Schwerin (CHRO), that the suggested timing is a 12-month scope. We ask so much of associates and have so much going on, we can start with the BCI in fall (sept-dec timing) but that the 2
nd
 sessions (and IDI) will follow in 2024. Does that make sense? I like the idea of a pulse versus getting it all done quickly, anyway, and the 2
nd
 session there will be time to pressure test "what have you been doing differently since we last met? How are things now?"
 
We are still figuring out if we do the leadership sessions in person or remotely. Or, maybe a combo, jumping in when they are all in person for another meeting/event.... To me, it makes no difference in person or remote in this post-covid age.
 
Thank you again for putting together the scope/budget/timing.
Tina
